review_text: Loved our days experience at Thredbo.  Took the Cooma Coaches shuttle bus up there from Jindy. Highly recommended
Been coming here for years, staff have become rude and snobby. Doesn't matter how much snow they'll take your money no problem but
Had fun filled weekend with my Grand Daughter & her family
AMAZING
Great for learner, intermediate to advance ski. No toboggan area for kids. Beautiful scenery and local stays.

Accommodation is pricey but mostly good and requires advance booking during the ski season. We had a nice little appartment with views of the ski slopes - thoughtfully assembled.

The local pool is great for those not in the ski slopes.

Service across the resort is erratic.  People from local region who regularly work at the resort, like the bus drivers,  are lovely and helpful.  But there are lots of 'itinerant' workers, esp in the cafes and restaurants, who are poorly trained and disinterested. The large american (?) woman manning the information centre  warrants special mention. She had her feet planted on the counter, her eyes firmly on her phone, as she dealt with our query about possible luggage storage with abrupt one word responses. In the scheme of things, these may not be deal breakers during a good snow season but it does colour your view of Thredbo as a supposedly upmarket ski resort and makes alternative ski destinations more attractive.

Start off by saying an amazing place, best place to ski in Australia by far, buller and hotham with good snow a distant second. Length of runs, height run quality all 5 out of 5.
Service probably to be expected with mine and the latest generations, maybe if we communicated with screens it would be better, the number of times we haven't been acknowledged, from cafes to lifties, just ignore your customers, no eye contact or banter, so weird when it should come so easily in this environment, and used to.
My gripe, again this is generational, all the advertising, seeing other countries you'd think we'd treat such a pristine location with more respect, rubbish everywhere, it's embarrassing and a blight on us as a society that we could just dump litter everywhere....
Will come back, please address this before it gets any worse
Thredbo  Alipne the best!
Impeccable treatment and 1000 points
Absolutely criminal pricing for lift passes during snow season. You should be ashamed.
Staff really no friendly, all of them looking like living the worst day ever
Nice rooms and batter service

Went to Friday Flat which is a ski resort just before Perisher and offers some good beginner terrain.. My kid took ski lessons there by really friendly instructors and kept a watch out for him falling over and gave him extra instructions and support. As a result my kid learnt how to ski in just 1 lesson.. pretty happy! Snow was great but very crowded!
Blue-bird day with clear skies and corduroy groomed runs
Leaving a review to shoutout the two lifties (Sam and James) manning the Alpine coaster on Tuesday August 11th. Excellent service and promptly sorted us with an issue we had the previous day!
Re skiing - not bad if you've got the money for it but the map isn't the best and the run markings aren't either. May need to be there early to park in the main car park if it's a busy day
Staffs are very kind, friendly and nice

i had a snowboarding lesson with my sister and i but we messed up the times luckily the staff were chill about it and allowed us to still do the lesson! Not only this but our teacher Jake! was the goat he was very chill and easy to talk to, i definitely felt wayyy more confident in snowboarding after the lesson! + the group we were in for the lesson were extremely funny!!! :) Shoutout jake we love you bro  give this man a pay rise he deserves it

I went to the park for the activities, but I wasn't staying at the hotel, so don't know about the rooms. But the place in general it's very nice, and I was quite surprised with vegan options at the local pub besides chips.
No spaces for nothing, impossible to park the car. More than 3 hours driving around and NOTHING.
Wow. Great experience and wonderful time. Plenty of parking and restaurants

Worst experience I ever had in this resort.

During peak season timings they expect us to be before 8am in mornings to have best possible coverage for 12-3pm pass session.

If you really want us to be early, make sure to "REMOVE" passes saying 12pm-3pm on website, and also never release tickets and overbook.
Must visit for ride coaster and gandola. Nice snowy atmosphere.

A systematic SCAM - AVOID!
Booked ski lessons plus ski lift pass, Travelled from Sydney, stayed the night in Canberra to split travel over 2 days, only to reach the front of the line and be turned back saying the road was closed. No Signage, no warning - just hours of long queues and they turn you back. They want you to buy the overpriced rubbish accommodation to allow entry and will not honour the ridiculously expensive activity bookings.
Was advised by the road officer that the closure was requested by the same business and that I should get a full refund. However, they are palming off any responsibility of the closure and only offering a credit. It's beyond imagination how many visitors they must have had and the amount money they must be making if they have had to close the roads, and they still want to keep the money from people who have not even been allowed entry - shameful.
I am definitely not up for spending another 2 days and another excess of thousand $ to utilise any credit they have to offer. Additionally, we had also rented all the skii/ snow play gear which is now a total waste. There is absolutely no snow at all before the park entrance, unsure after that.
There has been no communication from the business regarding the closure. Infact, when I reached out, I was advised that these closures are very common and I am surprised to see how poorly this is being managed.
Do yourselves a favour and look away from this place - it's absolute rubbish - ruined the entire holiday after all the time and money spent!

I've been skiing at Thredbo before and bought lift passes previously without issue. This year, I once again bought my passes online and uploaded them to the same plastic card I already had--a card I had to purchase separately in the past, which frankly is already an unnecessary cost.

But things took a turn for the worse.

In the afternoon, my son's pass stopped working out of nowhere. The card was in perfect condition--no bending, no visible damage. At the Merritts lift, we were told we'd need to get a new one. Assuming it was a simple swap (as it should be), we headed down to Guest Services.

To my disbelief, they refused to replace the faulty card for free, saying, "Oh, old ones sometimes stop working."
What the heck?! That's not my fault if the cards they issue are unreliable! Why should I have to pay another $5 to replace a broken card, especially when we've already paid a premium for the lift passes?

This kind of nickel-and-diming for something clearly outside the customer's control is ridiculous. At these prices, you'd expect basic customer service--not having to pay for the resort's poor-quality infrastructure.

Next time, I'll happily spend a little more to ski overseas for a longer, better experience. Thredbo seriously needs to rethink how it treats its customers. This left a bad taste.

The worst experience and frustration, from rude staff with no consideration/ compassion for the people, and this place is a scam , paid $320 ,  the place was overbooked and car park was full, but didn't get a refund, only a credit card, after travelling all the way from Canberra, only to be told car park full so road is closed: never sent any message email although they knew car park was full , didn't care for people coming from far
Love this pub, always great food & friendly service
Drove from Canberra, got just out of thredbo to be told there was no carparks!!should have been signs at Jindabyne!!PISSED OFF!!!

Was our go to mountain for 25 years. But these changes to season passes with no cheaper passes bought the year before, along with the stupidly mental increase in day passes, along with the failure to sell passes with flexible days, has meant we haven't been down in 3 years. We're starting to look at Japan / NZ now. Or possibly falls creek / VIC resorts. BOOOOO NEW THREDBO!

Absolutely Epic Days on the Slopes - Thredbo Delivers!
Thredbo Ski Resort is truly in a league of its own, and my recent visit was nothing short of a spectacular 5-star experience! From the moment we hit the slopes, it was clear that the conditions were phenomenal. The snow was incredibly good, offering perfect turns and a fantastic base that made every run a joy.

The runs themselves are just fantastic, catering to all levels with their diverse terrain, from wide-open groomers to challenging steeps and fun tree lines. The sheer vertical drop means you get long, exhilarating descents, maximizing your time on the snow. Beyond the skiing, the atmosphere around the village was just as fantastic - lively, welcoming, and with that undeniable Thredbo buzz. There's always something happening, adding to the overall vibrant energy.

And as the perfect way to cap off an amazing day on the mountain, that donut at the end of the day was a real winner - a sweet, warm reward that hit the spot perfectly! Thredbo consistently offers an unparalleled snow holiday. We absolutely loved it and can't wait to get back up there.
Everything was absolutely amazing, but you have to book online for the  or the chairlift wich we missed
Amazing place to experience snow
Loved it
Refuse for refund because by mistake put wrong email address and didn't get confirmation letter and barcode.
Amazing place but extremely expensive, it costs the same as an over seas holiday

Will not return, such a poorly organised place.
No car parks, have to drive around forever to find one, and if you find one you have to walk a mile to your room.
No tobogganing allowed, which is so ridiculous!
Nothing for children 4 and under to do.
Everything is closed by 6pm, everything seems so hard here!
Went on the gondola to the top, went to the cafe and wow... no seats inside at all.. have to stand for ages hoping someone would leave, unless you want to sit outside in the pouring rain. Ridiculous that there is no share outside to cover, I'm sure in both summer and winter this would be handy as you'd be protected from the sun and rain.
Absolute rip off everywhere you go here.
Have been to Mt Buller and can say that is worth every single cent, our choice of snow holiday will be mt Buller every time. will never return to Thredbo. Absolute crap. A HUGE waste of money.
Thredbo Ski Resort....great space, easy drive, excellent runs for snowboarding.

We were told to book tickets online, which we did, but when we arrived, due to strong wind, the ride was cancelled.  We came from far and for the whole family, a voucher to come back next time was offered to us!!!  I think a refund would have been a better option rather.
Very disappointing experience

Ideal for extreme skiing.
Ski resort
If you want to experience snowboarding and ski, it would be one of the best. Otherwise, perisher is good for normal family snow trip
We only visited for a few hours but it was snowing while we were there.
Super
Visited Thredbo for the first time and absolutely loved it - stunning mountain views, friendly atmosphere, and plenty to explore
We absolutely loved Thredbo. Family of 5 didnt find it too expensive. We just got the Gondola to the Gonolda Merrits and hung out in the snow and Cafe. Amazing experience
Great Place, Perfect to bring families and staying over in the resort nearby
Great area to ski, especially

All is good for the nature loving, heavon for the snow gamers, but there is no good for the non gamers. Gandola and  lifters are there, but they give prefferance to snow gamers. Normal tourist  should  be given better share in gandola and lifter. Good wishes n
Good fun - snow can be very icy and gets slushy towards the bottom of the mountain, but Thredbo is Australia's best ski resort
The most friendly Lifties around by far... so good always happy. with some great tunes on the mountain...  cheers guys

Great spot for everyone! Perfect conditions...
Instagram @ZahrinaArtist
This was a great experience with snow. Unlimited fun with nature's gift; it's a must-visit place.
First ever experience with the Snow in the heart of snowy mountain - Threadbo. Loved it and will be again travelling there later.

Plenty of slopes for all skill levels. John, our instructor for our ski lesson was very patient and a great instructor. The people operating the ski lifts and carpets are all very bubbly and kind. Great experience coming here and would definitely come back.
Treated Mt Kosciuszko like it was at the same level as Mt Everest, lied to me aswell telling me it would take me almost 10hrs to do the route. Cool place if you ignore the weird staff

They should not allow express payment through paypal/apple pay if it doesn't really work. I initially booked winter pass and paid through express payment (paypal)but apparently, it doesn't get through most of the time so they said to just book again directly to card as they can't do anything about it. But the price has already increased so I had to pay extra unnecessarily. I had wait for an hour to get connected to their service to confirm my booking only to be told to just make another booking. SO overrated and NOT kid friendly activities .
Thredbo is amazing!!

The alpine coaster is the only attraction that feels somewhat worth the money. Unfortunately, tobogganing isn't allowed, which would've been a great family activity. If you're looking for a better experience, head to Perisher Valley instead -- there's more snow, and you can enjoy snowboarding, skiing, tobogganing, and quality time with the whole family.
The place is nice for rides and lessons for ski but it's not a place for bellow 4 years old to play.
Amazing place in NSW...
Not for the family-friendly if you  do not know how to ski its just robbing place for you
Worst service possible!!! Way easier to use the app and not wait for non existent staff member!!!
spent dollar 80 per person yet the experience was worth it

Thredbo is a beautiful and magical place, especially after a heavy snowfall - it really feels like a winter wonderland! My son absolutely loved the Alpine Coaster, which was definitely a highlight of our trip. We tried to book three rides but unfortunately, it was all sold out, and there was only one ride option available - so make sure to book in advance.

The ski area itself is pretty good. We wanted to book a ski lesson at Friday Flat and got there around 12:35 PM for a 1:00 PM session, but were turned away because they require at least 30 minutes of prep time before the lesson starts. Something to keep in mind - get there early!

One thing to note is that Thredbo doesn't have a lot of dedicated areas for snow play with kids. Most of the snow play is either by the roadside or scattered around the ski resort, and unfortunately, tobogganing isn't allowed. On top of that, the Merritts Gondola was shut due to high winds during our visit.

While the snow and scenery were absolutely incredible, the infrastructure just doesn't seem to cope well during the peak school holiday season. Overall, a great experience but definitely one where planning ahead makes a big difference.
The best ski resort in NSW
beautiful place but very very crowded on a holiday

Don't buy the winter adventure pass, total rip off and even though we were partly refunded we realised it wasn't the correct amount. They tried saying the children were on a mates rate, which is false they had their own thredbo card. They paid the same as a friend est $55 who was refunded 37.50 while our two kids only got like 26ish back, but they all paid the same amount for the same ticket and pass.
Even with this part refund it works out we spent more then what it would've cost us if we just purchased the roller coaster separately.

The leisure centre is a dump, rock climbing wall falling apart. Gym 15yrs and older only, so not ideal if you have little kids. A couple ping pong tables. Tbh its not worth it, unless you're staying at thredbo for a long time and want that Gym session in, its not worth it. Also the trampoline inside is an extra $16, for a trampoline! Just save your money and skip it, it's not that great. The rest of thredbo is pretty but this was a let down and I wouldn't buy this pass or recommend it.
The merit gondola was also out of order. The main reason we bought the pass.

Disappointing experience at Thredbo. Poorly managed peak day

We were turned away by staff before even reaching the visitor gate after sitting in a car queue for over an hour, despite holding valid ski day passes. Our family had driven 5.5 hours and spent thousands of dollars on passes, only to be denied entry without warning until we reached the park entry gate

Thredbo seriously needs to reconsider how it manages crowds during peak periods. The car park was full, yet it seemed many people were just there to sightsee or take photos, not ski or snowboard. Meanwhile, paying guests were left stranded and turned away with no alternatives or real explanation.

Staff showed zero empathy as they directed cars away after a long wait, which made an already frustrating situation even worse. If you're going to oversell passes or allow non-skiers to take up ski parking, at the very least, communicate it properly or cap capacity.

You'd think they hadn't been operating for 60 years. What a joke.

Thredbo is an excellent skiing spot for every ski enthusiast.  It is an excellent place to visit for Canberrans as it's less than three hours away. You can both have a day trip or stay overnight if you wish to thanks to the lodges conveniently located at the sight, which will ofcourse be a little expensive.

For people with low budget their are heaps of motels in Jindabyne which is at a stretch of 30 minutes.

If you haven't bought your skiing gear already don't worry there are heaps of shops that lend them both in Jindabyne and in Thredbo.

To keep yourself warm you will find coffee shops in Thredbo, there are heaps of food options also available in Thredbo .
Absolutely Breathtaking location ans lots of fun activities for the family
Dropped my phone from the chairlift, patrol staff were extremely helpful, got it back within half hour.  Really appreciate.

Road closure on Alpine Way before queuing on line for 1 and a half hour, no information on the way. The worst ski service ever.
all ski hires are on the car and waste of our time and money. it took us days to travel there to know the road is closed. We went on Saturday afternoon.
not sure what time is it gonna open.
if you want to secure, you better book a thredbo resort, I think that's why it's cost triple the cost of stay there.
Very good point
Very good place to spend day with family
Tiff at Thredbo customer service went above and beyond to help. Problem solved and kids had a great time!
DIABOLICALLY PRICEY!!! Petty fascility
DONT GET SCAMMED BY PAYING LIFTPASS!!! Just come in with your gear and ski all you want. They will force you to pay $250 for a lift pass
The worst ski resort weve been skiing in. Way too crowded, price is crazy high. Its a waste of money to come here. Experience was real bad
Awesome ,  lucky it's sunny.
Definitely a place you shouldn't miss if you're in Canberra.
Amazing

Had a wonderful time with our stay here! 

Spent the time with hubby and friends. If your not good with good weather, wear thick clothes for winter and better rent some pants and shoes, all other supplies at Thredbo rentals. Supper enjoyed riding the coaster and Gondola. We also tried making our own Snowman! haha. They have the best Cinnamon doughnut, you have to try it at (i forgot the name haha) All other snacks and food are available at Friday Flat. CR are on the ground and 2nd floor!

If your looking for a Tour guide or something, we booked the Ozia Tours! Their tourguide is nice and friendly!

So fun just expensive, make sure to rent in jindy or even buy stuff on marketplace, take lots of food. it's just insane the prices of things

The Thredbo staff are all really lovely and the lessons were great, we thoroughly enjoyed our time and didn't have any moment of annoyance

Thredbo Alpine Village offered a fantastic snowy adventure for my toddler, who loved playing in the snow and riding the gondola. While the tobogganing was not allowed, the overall family-friendly atmosphere and variety of activities made it a memorable short getaway.
Good to ski and many activities
Thredbo is the best place for serious skiers. Really enjoyed the location and skiing. Kids had great time there as well.
Thredbo is OK. But the effects of climate change are obvious, and there is a lot of greenwashing about carbon offsets.
There are places in Australia where you can ski in June, but it's a long way from Sydney to the ski resort, and the ski resort service center is too small, so many things waste my time

Had a fantastic time skiing with my 3 kids at Thredbo. Thredboland for the 6-year-old was worth every penny, he loved it. The alpine coaster was a great experience at the end of the ski day. Thredbo is a beautiful spot worth visiting year-round. As a family promoted resort it would be nice to have a family ski pass. There were average snow conditions when we were there, but We would still come back
Perfect place to spend a holiday and great for people of all ages! First time this year and I'll definitely be back.

Great ski when snow top to bottom.
Not busy
Bluebird day
I was stunning experience playing with snow
Great day had and fun in the snow. Staff were really helpful and Gondola and Snow Coaster were great fun!

A Dreamy Winter Escape to the Snowy Mountains 
Our recent trip to the Snowy Mountains was nothing short of magical. From the breathtaking scenery to the fresh mountain air, everything felt like a winter fairytale come to life.

We visited Merritts Gondola, and wow -- what an incredible experience! Gliding over the snow-covered slopes with panoramic views was truly unforgettable. My children, saw snow for the very first time, and their pure joy and wonder made the entire trip even more special. Watching them build snowmen, laugh in the powder, and make snow angels is a memory I'll treasure forever.

The cozy alpine atmosphere, friendly locals, and the peaceful vibe made this the perfect winter getaway for our family. Whether you're chasing adventure or just want to curl up in a cabin with hot chocolate, this place has it all.

Highly recommend to anyone looking to create beautiful memories surrounded by nature, snow, and love.

In all honesty, Thredbo Resort is a truly exceptional place in Australia.  I've visited many times over the years, and the views continue to captivate me.  Jindabyne, at the foot of the mountain, boasts a lovely lake, and the town is idyllic when snow falls. However, please be mindful of road conditions and remember to pack snow chains, regardless of your vehicle, as driving can be challenging in snowy weather.

Please note people its a very busy resort at times and you will have to ensure your prepared to share the slopes!
The best

It was the best.
Start of the snow season
Best location and service
Very beautiful place
Great place
Amazing experience with snow fall, skiing, cold beer, cafe, views, gondolas, coaster... we spend 24 hours and everything was perfect... visit again whenever I got chance in future

Thredbo was an unforgettable experience for our family! I visited the ski resort with my parents (both around 55 years old), and it was their first time in the snow. I highly recommend Thredbo, not just for skiing, but also for the other activities. My parents didn't ski, but they thoroughly enjoyed the Merrits Gondola and Alpine Coaster, and were absolutely amazed! We also had a fantastic break at the top of the hill, relaxing with cold beers and delicious chicken. Thredbo is a must-visit destination for everyone.
it's beautiful place make sure to take extra clothes than normal chances of getting wet due to snow. One day is not enough
Beautiful little town. If the lift passes aren't so expensive, we'd visit the resort a lot more frequently.
Best place in Sydney

We have had a beautiful stay in Thredbo. Snow was falling the whole time.

Pretty disappointed we paid for winter passes yet everything was shut due to the weather.
Best food in the village, and seeing Mark Travis play live here is the best bit.
Best spot great roller-coaster

We decided to head to Thredbo to check things out. I must say, the village is so much bigger than I expected. We took the gondola up the mountain and enjoyed a lovely hot chocolate with some amazing mountain views.
Just before peak season is the time to go!
Very beautiful
Really good and awesome. Perfect for teenagers during the school holidays. So many trails to choose from that range from beginner to expert. I would go there a million times if I could.
Beautiful

Thredbo is an amazing destination for anyone who loves the mountains. Whether you're into skiing, snowboarding, hiking, or just soaking in the stunning views, this place has it all. The village has a charming vibe, with great restaurants, cozy lodges, and friendly locals. The slopes are well-maintained, and there's something for every skill level. Thredbo is definitely a must-visit for nature lovers and adventure seekers alike!
Exorbitant prices
Stayed at Snow Goose apartments - great location!

Amazing place, we went there in Summer, lots to do around. You can start your summit to Mt. Kosciuszko here. Great place for the entire family. Hiking, biking you name it. Can be pricey, but definitely worth it.

Didn't stay but the village is very cute. The small creek/brook is very pretty and the wildlife too. Visited in early autumn, scenic pass was fun, never been on a chairlift so that was nice. Enjoyed the cafe at the top of the Kosciuszko lift and the alpine coaster was absolutely brilliant. It is a bit pricey but it is quite the experience and I would recommend it since it is fun, however for visitors in the area, like myself, that may not already be aware, you need a National Park pass to enter the national park, and thus Thredbo. If you enter the park, you don't need a Thredbo pass to visit the village and the shops but you do need it for the chairlifts and attractions.

The crew here at the pub, were efficient friendly and welcoming.
Couldn't ask for a better night

Didn't  stay in accommodation so I can't rate that. I wanted to but not that rich.
We went as a family to walk to Kosciusko. Of course the walk was great and Mother Nature was to.
Thredbo Village itself looks very tired and worn out. Everything is overpriced and there is not actually much there.
Struth it's a long way away, but it's nice.
Great place. Mountain biking on steroids
Beautiful location
The biking is incredible.
Good spot away from the crush but close enough to join in if needed

My initial reaction for the price of our $510 two night summer stay was , well, bloody hell!
(winter peak will be around $500 a night)
Included in the price was a day pass to all the lifts operating and a cut lunch was provided for our stroll up to Mount Kosciusko, and quite honestly that took the sting out of the price tag.

It is a 68 year old Hotel, that has some signs of wear and tear and the room was a little pokey and hot, but it definitely has an old world charm about it.
The staff were nothing short of fantastic, friendly and attentive.
The local pub owned by the resort was OK and served reasonably good meals at a fare price.
The buffet breakfast was also included in the price, but dont get too excited about that, it was Ok, but hot food was not that hot, however there was lots of other choices.
I imagine car parking would be a problem during the peak season.
All up, yes it is worth the trip and cost
just Awesome
Lovely place for spending holidays. We enjoyed mountain biking and alpine coaster the most.
Great chairlift accessed mtb trails, suitable for  a wide range of riding abilities. Every other Aussie ski resort should take note of what Thredbo is doing.
Drive past
It was an amazing experience, especially so by the fact that in November there was still heaps of snow up on the higher platue.
Heaps of activities,  food options and the aquatic centre was fun with slide and inflatable obstacle course
Beautiful walk from Perisher to Bullocks Flat
We stayed at Jindabyne and traveled to Thredbo village for the day. Quaint  village  with a great pub
Great place for a day trip in summer. Recommend buying a ticket for the ski lift going to the top and walk the remaining distance to the top of Kosciuszko
Way over priced , Thredbo management have lost their grip on reality

To the all those staff members and fellow Mtb'ers who helped evacuate my littleman 13yrs off the hill on Thursday...
Thank you so so much..
As with these kind of sports it's only a matter of time...
Broken collar bone..
Lexi, you are an absolute champion. Professional friendly and super helpful...
The doctors at the leisure centre were perfect. I couldn't ask for better care in trying circumstances. Fast effective triage and quick  X-rays..
He was getting fast, right up until he wasn't..
Thredbo was stunning. Thredbo Hotel staff were amazing and went above and beyond in service.
Top bike park, no doubt about it

Summer in threadbo not bad. Full of mountain bikers goin' up in the ski lift .lots of trails ,views. Food is very pricey.who pays $20 for a cheeseburger! Nope went to the local .wasn't much cheaper but more food for $20. Prices are over the top. $65 for an all day ski pass. That doesn't help a tourist who just wants to experience the ride up and back or have lunch up in the restaurant at the top. 130$ for 2 of us just for one trip.nope. they don't do that ,you have to buy a pass. We don't want a pass so we missed out and so did they. weather has been brilliant. Havnt been here since my younger days and it's still stunning even in summer

One of the best place to enjoy nature.

Staff in Thredbo village are friendly and helpfull.

Sometimes i went there and stay in Motel, and sometimes do the camping  as well as remote camping.
I love hiking here in the warmer months. Beautiful waterfalls, scenic views, delightful wildflowers.

As always, a magnificent mountain location.

However, the predominance of mountain biking in the summer seems to have led to a general loss of amenity in the village for the non-biking visitor.

We found the Thredbo Alpine Hotel and the Denman Hotel both excellent.  Particularly the Denman restaurant, where the food and service was exceptional.

Enjoyed the Thredbo experience. Ski lift and alpine roller coaster package was quite good value over 5 days. Enjoyed the hikes. Information services could be improved, particularly the knowledge of people about hikes in the service areas and available information brochures. The Ap is also limited.

Awesome spot, lots to do and very scenic.
Only reccomendations I can give are bring sunscreen and areogard
Oh, and prolly avoid falling off you bike... That guy looked like he was in a lot of pain.

I love Thredbo in the summer when the place is thronged with MTB bikers and hikers of all ages and expertise. As a keen walking I know the paths well and must ring a word of warning to those new to this wonderful retreat...the paths on the mountain are deteriorating rapidly from overuse and lack of sufficient maintenance. As well the intermediate Merritt-Meadows walk has had its signage messed up by the installation  of the new (and fun!) Coaster. The walk, either way, between  Dead Horse Gap and the  Top Station has become deeply rutted and difficult to negotiate

It's a fantastic spot for hikers and nature enthusiasts. However, the booking process could be a bit tricky. They advertise discounts online and even mentioned savings when I spoke to them. But when I booked online, I was charged the full amount. The website doesn't make it easy to understand bundle bookings for activities , and I ended up paying more than I should have. Oh, and the chairlift we wanted was out of order because of maintenance, but the convenience and alternative options weren't handled very well.

Despite all these issues, I had a wonderful time on our hike. It was so relaxing and enjoyable!

Thredbo is great in the summer with nature walks and hikes, mountain biking, usually pretty clean air, less pollution and cooler temps. It's not cheap, though. People are always pleasant, both guests and staff. We love it. Quality of accommodation is variable but generally you get what you pay for.
Had a blast.

I am speaking only from my own experience in Thredbo during the summer. The town itself wasn't worth staying overnight in, as pretty much everything closes after 5pm except for a Mexican restaurant, which was average at best. It is best to stay in Jindabyne instead, which is a 30-minute drive away and cheaper. It's a fantastic trip, however, for the top of the mountain and the activities offered during the day.
Great place and friendly staff.
Ideal for bikers and skiers

It was sick. I bet the boys I could charge up that mountain in less that halfa. I lost that bet.

Lack of a vibe in November though, and nothing was open. How am I meant to buy tins when the IGA is closed!?

A dump. The place was deserted except for cleaners and workers. Road signs saying roads closed ahead that weren't.
Was going to get the chairlift up to walk Rams Head.
Koso express was shut and the other option would add half hour to our walk.
And the wanted to charge $52 each. Mid week in off season.
What a joke!
Alot to see and do. Very popular during the winter months. You can play in the snow, have a drink at the pub, sit by the fire and have a ride on the alpine coaster.

This was my first time skiing ever, and I'm so glad that it happened here, this place is not only gorgeous but way to much fun - I went here with friends with some of us being already adept
Skiers and others (like me) going for the first time. But regardless we all had the best time. We stayed in the river inn which was very accomodating for both kids and adults alike. And sits directly across from the slops with a pathway connecting them - making travel to and from the slopes unbelievably convenient. And the slopes themselves were gorgeous, though over the course of the stay become more melted, and while the slopes were fine the general area at the bottom was far from it.
Lovely place to visit. Even in spring with lots of tracks and walks available.
We went there during autumn and it was still great! We went up mount kosiosco, saw all the beautiful wildlife and went on multiple hiking trails. All in all a wonderful experience!

Good resort, good runs and diversity in slopes available. Expensive AF but I guess you're paying for the convenience of having slopes and snow a drive away from Sydney. Make the most of it before the show all melts
It was nice to visit
Really nice place to visit. People are friendly. The Kosciuszko area is lovely.
It was closing down as it was end of ski season still a beautiful place to visit.

Be careful booking in advance! Booked lessons for kids, ski hire and lift passes for the family when there was 14/15 lifts in operation. They had rain the weekend before we went and then large winds on the day. They offered a credit if we decided to cancel on the morning of, but telling a 5 and 8 year old that we are skiing anymore is not an option. End result, they had 1/15 lifts open for the majority of the day, and 2 open for the back half. I requested a discount (on the parents tickets only) given the significantly reduced quality of their service compared to when I booked and they said no, it's not within their terms and conditions.
Terrible customer service for a clearly reduced service. I'll take my annual ski trip elsewhere from now on.
Always great to be in the mountains.
Yum

Great place for skiing, hiking, well equipped with needed amenities food, drinks, skiing shopping, rentals.

Great vibe wonderful place with family and friends. Close to this vicinity plenty of restaurants and pubs. We spent 3 nights here while skiing which was a memorable experience. 100% we would be visiting again.

The Gondola ride and Kosciusko chairlift are not operational on most of the days during winter. But people book those before visiting Thredbo. It will be sold out on weekends, but won't be operational. When you check in the counter, they say it is not operational due to the wind and they will give credit which can be used for Alpine Coaster. As you would have already gone once on Alpine Coaster, you dont want to take the same ride multiple times. You can see that the chairlifts in Friday flat are operational, but not the Kosciusko chairlift. They won't refund the tickets for Gondola ride and Kosciusko chairlift. If you check in the counter, they will ask you to call the guest services. If you call them, they will ask you to send an email. If you send an email, they won't respond. If you call them multiple times after sending email, they will mention that you have used the credits in a restaurant or a retail shop. While you have used your own credit card in the restaurant, they try to give all kinds of excuses, and avoid the refund. I was near the counter and saw that many people are facing the same issue when they visited Thredbo.

The rating for Thredbo on Google reviews is 4.5, but when you scroll down all the reviews, you will see that most of them have rated single. It should have actually been single star.
Not family friendly at all. Unless you are going to ski, there is really no space for children to play.
Even with the weather being less than desirable they held everything together and I've an fantastic time. I'll be back :))

We did not stay at Thredbo but went to snowboard as a day trip with a large number of first time, children snowboarders. Firstly the snow and weather were against us with poor snow, recent rains and high winds closing most of the resort and only the Gunbarrell and Easy Does It lifts operating in the morning. This and limited snow coverage made the slopes crowded and the closure of Gunbarrell early pushed everyone onto the one lift and slope. Having said that and understanding that this is out of the control of the resort, the staff and facilities were amazing. The hire shop staff suited up and kitted out over 40 kids and adults in under half an hour, snowboard instructors were excellent and the patrol crew happily showed the kids through the rescue equipment.   The food was excellent with tons of choices and was reasonably priced. A great day all round.

A beautiful place to visit, we all love it there. Good vibes, great skiing, fab food, but pricey but to be expected for Australian snow resorts! Special mention to some of the awesome shuttle bus drivers around the mountain - always a laugh!
Great to spend the day as a family

Where to even start with this place!? It has the potential to be great. Thredbo village is beautifully nestled in between the mountain hills with a lovely river running through it.

Yet there is nothing going on, hardly any restaurants, hardly any bars and the same with shops. The restaurants are terrible quality that you wouldn't serve food to your dog, staff rushed off their feet so the service is god awful.

It's just a bad bad experience. Unsure if this is Australia Tourism that doesn't want to pump money in or it's just been monopolied by one owner and they don't want to build anything else?

Either way. It's no place to host thousands of people every day. Cannot be catered for what so ever!

Ski passes at over $200 per day as well. You can see why people just go elsewhere.

I won't ever be returning. Spend your money elsewhere

People who are not interested in skiing and snowboarding should consider purchasing the $85 Adventure Pass. This pass includes unlimited access to the Merritts Gondola for up to 3 hours, one ride on the Alpine Coaster, and one entry to the Leisure Centre. The Merritts Gondola is a cable car that accommodates up to 8 people.

Please note that the pass costs August 19 2024 , $85, plus a $5 card fee. Any date changes or modifications will incur a $20 fee

I just want to give some positive feedback following one of the tours I took at Thredbo Resort.

I booked a Backcountry Snow Shoeing tour for Tuesday 2 July 24 1pm session. It was my first time in the backcountry and snow shoeing and it was incredible. But what made it really exceed my expectations was the tour Guide Simme (apologies if I didn't spell that right), she was just awesome. Her knowledge was outstanding and her enthusiasm for the region and the tour was what really made for a truly incredible experience. It's great to be around people that love what they do.

Please pass on my sincere thanks and gratitude to Simme, she was truly awesome.

Thredbo Skiing Review

We recently stayed at Kasees Lodge, and the experience was a mix of highs and lows. The lodge itself is fantastic with brilliant and friendly staff who made us feel welcome.

However, the overall experience at Thredbo was quite disappointing. Policies seem rigid, and even the staff appear unaware of them, often leading to arguments and a lack of support. For instance, our interaction with guest services left us stunned. When asked about a half-day lift (this was at 14:30 pm ), the response was, "That's the policy, do you want it or not? No skin off my nose, mate!" This dismissive attitude was shocking.

The ski school for kids was great, but if your child falls sick, you're out of luck. There's only one doctor, and the consultation fee is $110 with no refund, only Thredbo money. This lack of flexibility is frustrating.

My wife wanted to rent just skis, but was told it's not possible in case the boots aren't up to scratch, despite the same boots being sold next door. Even hotel staff recommended we go to Jindabyne instead.

Customer service here turns minor issues into major ones with their 'it's your problem, not mine' attitude. For any issues, you need to escalate to higher management levels.

In summary, while the location and some services are excellent, the rigid policies and poor customer service overshadow the positives. There needs to be a focus on customer-centric policies and better staff training to make Thredbo truly enjoyable for everyone.

I wouldn't recommend it cheaper and friendlier in Japan or NZ even mount Buller they are grateful for the visit as well as Perisher. Avoid Thredbo!

An amazing place for winter sports and in summer too. People is super nice, and the snow vibes are everywhere. The place is well prepared for families, adults and children. I definitely will come back

Thredbo is a fantastic resort with lots of very steep and very long runs. Perfect resort to be entertained on Australia's longest runs if you're an expert. Thredbo makes some of Australia's best skiers. The runs are no where near as busy as other resorts around it.

Very mixed experience from an absolute novice perspective. Drove with friends from Yarrangobilly for one day ski adventure (no hotel stay).

Good:
- After getting hands on skiing it was very fun.

Bad:
- There was one person at the counter and processing time was very slow. Considering cold temperature you'd like it to be a bit faster.
- The price was outrageous. Yes, I rented the ski and a helmet, but a few hundred+ dollars for a day is not worth it.
- The process of getting the gear was slow - I know it is a relaxed mountain atmosphere but sometimes the work needs to be done. Plus helmets are cleaned rarely or not properly or not cleaned at all - nobody provided a hair protection and it smelled.
- It was my first time skiing - there was absolutely ZERO support or introduction which is bananas considering the price paid. I mentioned many times that I need a help and nobody paid attention. When I barely walked in skis to what looked like a training session which I wanted to join - instructor turned me away because it must be booked. I stayed in skis like an idiot not knowing how to proceed next. If not my friends who are experienced skiers - I'd definitely injured myself attempting to figure out things just by looking at others. Think about it - driving hours on mountain road, excited to try skiing and then be literally abandoned. Shock.
- Cafeteria facilities are extremely primitive. Processed food like reheated frozen pies and hot dogs and some alcohol - there is definitely a room for improvement.

We stayed at the ski in ski out chalet by the Supertrail and it was amazing. I like how Thredbo has free shuttles to go around the resort. I also like there are nooks and crannies to explore if we're not on the trail. I would love to return and hopefully winter is better next year.

Lots of stores, restaurants, convenience snack stores and, of course, the ski and snowboarding area.

My only recommendation is to not buy the lift pass if you are a beginner at these sports, as they lead you to the more difficult areas, which beginners are not allowed to go down.
I pais $200 for the lift pass and wasn't allowed to use.

Another thing to have in mind is that any piece of guidance from the coachs, are paid. If you need instructions, you will need to pay for it, and the rangers will make sure you know it every time you ask a question or tip about skiing or snowboarding.

The local restaurants are overpriced on their menu as most of the things you will find for sale there.

Well where to start ... I guess my former loyalty. Skied there since I was 10, then worked for Thredbo (in hotel) after uni for 2 seasons ... and skied ever since till age 48 (typically twice a year). Skied Perisher once, never Victoria.  So formerly super loyal.

I forgave the greed and reduced services over COVID to an extent. For example as a snowboarder, not bothering to build a park when Sydney was excluded was just petty cost cutting.

However the 2022 season was embarrassing. Bulls balls and not much else at the much loved Black Sallees will cost you guys a lot more than the small extra margins you made last year. Probably my missing spend alone will make your decisions bad business...

The atmosphere is being crushed, the special vibe that did make Thredbo great is fading. The independent operators added intangibles that made the place great.

I've not even mentioned lift ticket prices ... I'd actually be more than happy to pay $200 per day if the place were special.

My advice is stay away a couple years, wait for the CEO to change, then give it a go in 2025.

Big safety issues regarding the chair lift and operating of the chair lift. Requesting a formal incident report.

My son had an incident this morning (6th July Thursday) at the Cruiser Chairlift at Therdbo.

He was adjusting the skii poles when he slipped off the chair lift at the start of the ride, however the chairlift kept dragging him along until it reaches the first Tower, where he couldn't hold on anymore, so he dropped off to the ground, which is more than 4 -5 metres high as I've told ( the chair lift was lifted around the First Tower)

I drove back to Therdbo from Jindabyne when I heard the incident from his sibling.  I met snowsports manager and WHS manager at the medical clinic, where my son was sent to for checkups. (Being said that, I want to express my appreciation to the Snow patrol staff, who took the swift action to send my son to medical centre.)

When I arrived, a doctor did the examination for him, luckily, he had only a wrist fracture, considering fell off from this height.

I have raised concerns to the WHS manager regarding the operating of the he chair lift, and the safety of the chairlift:  why the chairlift didn't stop earlier when he fell off, instead it dragged him all the way to the first Tower. Also why would the chair lift still opetate when the safety handle isn't clicked in properly.

The WHS manager just said  that  they will investigate into the incident, but I wasn't  given any more details regarding the incident.

At the end, I've been requested to pay $596 examination fee for check ups and treatment at the medical centre,  (which I think should be covered by the centre, including the ongoing medical cost for treating his fractured wrist. )

Afterwards, I've been escorted to the parking and farewell with the centre staff. Then I realised that I didn't get any report of the incident or anything in written regarding the incident, not even a contact email from either of the managers. I felt great uncomfortable of been left blinded about the progress of the incident. So I've sent email to the customer service around lunchtime (that's the only contact of the centre I can find) but I haven't got any response yet (not even an reply saying they're looking into the issue).

Overall, I'm disappointed with the safety measures in Thredbo and not satisfied with the way how the centre handles the incident.

If there is any safety mechanism in place, the lift sould stopped when the safety handle is not clicked in properly; If the chair lift can be stopped earlier, my son would not had the fracture at all. The incident happened at the very beginning of the ride, but the chair lift didn't stop on time.

I urge the centre to seriously look into the security issues related to the chair lift, and review the process of how to
dealt with incident. I can not imagine how my son felt when he was hanging off the lift and been dragged up to the first Tower.

I hope this kind of incident will not happen to other kids in the future.

Looking forward for an apology and formal incident report from the centre ASAP.

Great ski resort and some of the best slopes. But worst customer service. Only one lift is open today due to strong winds. This is my first day here. I actually walked the gate at the ski lift and it scanned my card then the guy said only one lift is open today, so I said no point can I leave the line then. I'll go back to my room. He said yeah go for it. I then went to the kiosk desk and said what other options do I have as I never got to ski. She goes ring this number and they can sort out a reimbursement or a credit to spend at the local shops. She gave me the customer service business card. I rang them up and they said oh you already tapped your card. We can't help you. No refund for you no reimbursement nothing. Can't help you. I said well the lady at the kiosk said to ring up and she said im illegible for such compensation. The customer care lady said no that's incorrect. I said well there has been some miscommunication then and someone doesn't know what they are talking about. She said sorry can't do anything. My friend also rang the same customer care line because he also couldn't get on the lifts. However he never went through the bomgate for the lift but I did. That's complete absurdity. I said check the cameras. Ask the lift staff. I never went on the lift. Walked through the gate only to find out its one lift open so I left. She refused to help in any way or form. I have worked in customer service for 5+ years and I know how I would like to be treated as a customer. Thumbs down for this one guys. Poor absolute poor service. Won't be coming back again in the near future.. Remember tickets are not cheap either. I paid a lot for them.

Negligence literarily almost killed me

Being a highly ranked Google Reviewer, I like to be generous with my reviews and I don't usually like to complain about minor things, as humans, none of us are perfect. So please see my other reviews before judging me as some kind of Karen who likes to complain about everything

Having said that, Thredbo is a beautiful villiage, and the staff are extremely friendly. The staff are the only reason why this review is as high as it is, and the only reason I'd ever consider returning. Most staff that is. Negligence almost killed me, but I'll elaborate on that later. Most of the staff are absolutely wonderful people, and don't deserve to be tarnished with this brush. However, that's pretty much where the praise ends

Thredbo is extremely overpriced. I'm not even sure that it's legal for any company to price gouge as much as Thredbo does. And unfortunately, you don't really get much in return for your money.

Thredbo benefits from the fact that NSW has very few places where one can visit to see snow without skiing/snow boarding, and price gouges because of that monopoly. Other places that have to try to atteact skiiers when non-skiiers/snowboarders can visit other places in their country to see snow don't really price gouge. Despite the fact that many non-skiiers/snowboarders visit Thredbo, allowing them to price gauge in the first place, they don't really do much to accommodate us. Considering that Australia's lack of places to enjoy snow without participating in snow sports is why they can price-gouge in the first place, you think they'd do more to accommodate us. Instead, we're confined to the one mountain where most of the space is used by various ski trails.

I can understand that the ski industry was one of the hardest hit by Covid, as most Covid restrictions happened in winter, and I am truly happy to see them recover, however, the level of price gouging is ridiculous. Think of any other place which is known for price gouging- sports stadia, Uluru, other neiche resorts? I've been to those places, and Thredbo beats them hands down. The bulk of this low review is based solely on price gouging. I also understand that Thredbo is a seasonal destination with a small window to make a profit, but there are other places, and they don't price gouge the way that Thredbo does. Nor is Thredbo remote enough to justify it. I seriously can't understand how any of this is legal. With all the price gouging, I hope that the staff are at least paid well. Most of them definitely deserve it. The worst part, it's not just one or two areas that have price gouging. That would be mostly forgivable. It's everything, food, beverages, accommodation, everything. And the bulk of the reason why the review is as low as it is.

And I mentioned earlier that most of the staff are excellent. Well, there was an incident where a staff member put me in literal mortal danger. I won't dwell on this too much because I have contact the resort about it, and I believe that they are genuine about trying to rectify it. I also believe that the staff member put me in danger because of poor training, rather than anything within her control. Even though I suffered a minor injury which was worse than I originally thought it was, I'll happily wear that knowing that my near death potentially saved at least one life.

However, a handful of staff members completely ignored my distressed cries for help, leaving me in danger. I had to he rescued by random passers by. Those staff members who left me in danger were not reflective of the bulk of the staff, who, as I reiterate, were immaculate

But without even considering the incident that almost cost me my life, based on the price gouging alone, it's no wonder everyone goes skiing overseas. The bulk of the low review is based on the price gouging alone. If you had to choose between Thredbo and overseas, chose overseas. Less price gouging. And considering that Australia's skiing conditions are mediocre at best, the price gauging is especially not worth it

They say a lot about how expensive it is in Australia to ski. I don't disagree. But! When you look around at the facilities, a gondola, efficient chairlifts, huge amount of snow making machines, ample restaurants, bars, food and entertainment venues I think the price makes sense. All in all what isn't expensive in Australia!?

The snow cover was excellent even though the mountain had been soaked in a downpour a week prior, in fact so badly did it rain and wind blow, the mountain was closed a rare event. So I was a little cautious about buying a lift pass, but recent cold weather meant the guns were topping up the lower mountain and the upper had drained well and received 1/2 foot top up in the previous 24 hours. I got top to bottom skiing in from the highest lifted point all the way to the village. The weather was sensational. When australia gets it right, good weather and good snow seriously it's hard to beat how enjoyable it is. Thredbo has the longest thigh burning runs in Australia. So good!

Friday Flat rentals and gift store needs an update and some air freshener I know boots smell but the air is a bit 

Overall. Well worth the visit. Publicly available information about snow depth and weather updates mean the decision is yours, pick the right day after a snowy Antarctic cold front has swept through replaced by a stationary high pressure system sat on top of the mountain and you'll have a great time!
Fabulous weather, not so much snow sadly.
Very nice place

Great place to come skiing snowboarding and lots of wildlife in and around the village
Lots of things to do and see.

My first time to the snow so don't really have anything to compare it to! Thredbo is great for beginners, and also offers a great mix of easy to difficult slopes.

The staff are always so friendly and willing to help. The facilities are set up quite well. Getting in early to the carpark definitely helps (particularly during school holidays), as does carrying ski boots instead of walking with them on after you have parked!

If you need to hire snow gear, try to do so outside of Thredbo (e.g. in Jindabyne). Hiring equipment at Thredbo can be quite expensive.

If you are new to skiing, definitely book a lesson well in advance to arriving, stick to the magic carpet runs for the first day, and make sure you master braking before anything else!

Somewhat interesting runs if you're lucky with snow (tends to get icey), but overpriced and more importantly, filled with very rude people, had several experiences of demanding arrogant Karen's with private school kids telling me what to do for some reason when I was just minding my business. These people shouldn't be allowed out of Sydney. This is mostly aimed at fellow skiers and businesses in town but to some extent the staff here as well were surprisingly rude compared to other places I've skied. Kind of soured the experience which should have been amazing.

Centre is not  well heated, showers and change rooms are freezing and outdated, no hot pools to relax the muscles after a long day on the mountain  just a semi-heated lap pool, and water slide, inflatable aqua challenge is an extra $9 per child.

Really the Thredbo team should vist Japan and model a large family onsen.

Transport around the village is fabulous, did not have to wait more than 8 minutes for a ride and its FREE.

The communucation with the people  is horrible. I had to cancel my stay with them because of the recent lockdown in Sydney. And dealing with them was horrible after that.
Yes as per the policy in Austalian consumner laws you are not entitled for the refund if you are affected by lockdown, but I have many number of examples were the owners and the company have givin a full refund to their customers as a gesture of the goodwill.

When asked about the refund first of all they were very rude in their reply and I felt that I was robbing them, what I asked was a refund of my hard earned money.

After some email exchanges they agreed to refund 70% of the total amount and If i have any dispute on this I have to go the the local court.
Also to my suprise they gave me a 16 hour window to agree to this or else this refund will not be avaialble and I need to go for the court.

This whole communication is 8 days prior to the chek-in date.

I understand that why only owners needs to gets effected by this bu my question is why do they want the customers to suffer and loose their hard earned money due to a reason which they are not at all resposible for.

And they way they respoded was so rude and harsh without any consideration.

Our first visit to Thredbo, the weather was a little cool and overcast, we went on the snowgum chairlift as it was the only one operating on the day. After getting off we then hiked up to the Kosciuszko lookout. Then we decided to do the walk to the summit. By r time we got to the top it was foggy no views. My fit bit told me it was 7.49 km and it took 1.5 hrs each way. Just make sure you have warm clothes drink a a few snacks too keep you going. I'm in my late 50's and it was a little had going

I had a great day with the wife and son in Thredbo, a little early for snow but a nice sunny day. We had lunch at the local bakery which was a little expensive for two salad roles and two drinks but delicious none the less with the extra company of the local birds. Friendly people in the area as a guess most are tourist as are we. Negative would only be no safe access for prams and wheelchairs i.e lifts or safe pathways to the rear shops, the danger of being bowled over by the many bike riders that seem to not worry about a mother pushing a pram, maybe just on our day but a great place for holiday memories.

Village is lovely,  it was quiet when we visited , nice bakery . Chair lift to top $ 45 ea . Walk to look out to Mt Kosciuszko or go all the way , on a metal boardwalk , steepish in places , lovely scenery with patches of snow .walk along the river .

Thredbo was always the nicer area for less passionate skiiers....those who wanted charm, a feeling of a European ski village and field, the dedicated skiier goes to Perisher higher and more reliablable for snow ..less commercial.
Sadly the beautiful park with two duck ponds has been turned into a bike park so expensive apartments and lodges look onto screaming bike enthusiasts which I know is a family pass time however I am sure there was a less invasive spot to put it.
Sorry charm has gone....in a beautiful spot......shame!
Great place year round.
We will be back and will be staying at river side cabins again .

Interesting place in Summer there is a 25km walk with great views.
But mostly uphill so be prepared, it can get windy and cold at the top.
It can get very busy on weekends and Public Holidays as many people take on the challenge of this walk. There is a designated elevated steel  grate to walk on this is  to protect the flora and fauna. Please note , you have to take the chairlift up to the beginning of the walk.

The place itself is amazing the people that run it and how it's run it's a joke, they took up 90 minutes of our time so we didn't have time to do the hike to Kosciusko could only get to the lookout as the chairlift stop at 4.15, way over priced, hikers pay the same price for chairlift as mountain bikers do and we used it once and they use it all day.

I've been in both winter and autumn. Most recently in autumn and I did a couple of nature walks there - my lack of fitness not withstanding this was a very enjoyable experience. The scenery was beautiful and the village had some decent food on offer. Overall a great outing!
An amazing resort for any time of the year.

Had an absolute blast last week MTB'ing with a mate and our three sons.  The Flow trails are exciting and challenging for all levels of experience.  The hire staff were great and sorted out an issue of Nike size for one of our little fellas. Will definitely head back, got the bug now...

At the Thredbo centre where they sort tickets and at the bobsled there was a guide called Mads who was very helpful and even with all the COVID restrictions meaning people were sometimes less than patient she was happy and helpful. Also the staff at the pub were amazing. There were a lot of places not open for food so they got absolutely smashed with over 200 orders on the line. Despite this every staff member was lovely and worked very hard to get meals out in a timely fashion. Food was delicious as well!
Best place to shred all year round!!
It's quite nice place for summer

I'm sorry, I have to share this - When we were purchasing tickets to hire a bike we had in mind to ride down the mountain. The woman selling the tickets insisted it was a very steep descent from top to bottom, convincing me that it wasn't for me. We spent the day riding the tracks at the bottom, which were very enjoyable.

At the end of the day, we went to check out the mountain riders, and to my disappointment I saw horizontal-ish descents ridden by children! Oh and they're all male! Only one conclusion - the staff member looked me up and down, and stereotyped me as a woman, concluding I'd be too uncoordinated and fearful to have a go at the so-called "steep descent".

Unhappy I missed out on the opportunity based on gender stereotyping. Thanks Thredbo, I didn't need yet another person in my life holding me back from my athletic potential.

TO ALL GIRLS WHO GO TO THREDBO IN THE SUMMER, RIDE BIKES DOWN THE MOUNTAIN, YOU'LL HAVE A BLAST!!!! USE THE TRACKS AT THE BOTTOM FOR PRACTICE BEFOREHAND IF YOU NEED!!!!
Best ski resort in Australia - winter and summer!
A real playground in the kosiousko national Park. Snow ski runs in winter and great walking tracks for summer. Chair lift to Eagle nest restaurant. Very crowded on Xmas holidays.
Beautiful views a bit of a walk away...on the highest point in Australia

Had a great time riding Cider such a beautiful animal.

Thredbo Village is so well managed and organized by the locals, that makes the stay and fun in the valley so amazing for the visitors. Thredbo Ski resort is so amazing for the skiing and Ice Board enthusiasts to enjoy there. I will recommend the future visitors to book the accommodations, park tickets and passes well in advance to enjoy to the fullest. Free Shuttle service is available to commute to 3 routes available there in the peak season.

Had a great weekend with friends, hit up the mountains two days in a row Staying in Jindy. But Thredbo, what are you up to? There was snow making top to botto on 1-2 select runs, although it was very clear that many runs where snow making should have been in operation wern't (particularly on the Village Terminal side of the mountain"). Everything below mid-station on the Kosciuszko side was extremley marginal. And Midstation wasn't operational (hardly ever is apparently), so you are forced wade through about 1-2 km of  absolute slush, ice and dirt, back to the village.  Practically no grroming was done outside of Friday Flats (which was a nice soft beginers area, well stocked with manmade snow - that was absent from gun lined runs hundreds of metres up the mountain). Now the resort is not to blame for rain and soft snow (well they charge as if they are Whistler, but deliver as if they are early season Grouse), but the resorts claim of a "natural depth' of 1m this past weekend, is entirely laughable and false advertising. I mean dirt patches are visable on the webcams at 1800 or so metres. I know Covid has put pressure on bussiness models and forced resorts to save money, but I am still paying $152 for lift passes for a resort that cant open major runs and lifts in Mid-August due to a failure to snow make. The food and drink and everything is all standard ski resort stuff, nothing special. The lifties are friendly and helpful. The vibe amongst the crowd is good. The runs that are open are varied and challenging enough for me who is an ocassional but confident skiier. The new Gondola to Merrits is nice, but the crowds and constant 15 minute waits at the Cruiser chair highlight the need for some investment on this side of the mountain.  A quad to the top of Waimea would split the crowds and open up the top of that section to lots of skiers who arent going to schlep across to the constantly wind-held T-bars in between the two main areas. They are kind of a duopoly for Sydney based skiers, so i supose the 'we are joint #1 so why try harder' attitude is hear to stay.
Always confirm your passes before coming

If ZERO stars was an option for the My Thredbo Card I would select ZERO stars. NEVER load your money onto the card. Many of the restaurants and retailers at Thredbo DO NOT accept this card. Thredbo management will NOT REFUND any money remaining on the My Thredbo Card back to your credit card at the end of your trip either. Therefore, if you had $5,000 loaded onto your card and were not planning to return to Thredbo anytime soon, you can say goodbye to your money.... It seems a little unfair to me. What do you think??

Great place for hikes in the summer. Went here in November and the higher areas of the mountain still had some snow patches. We did a 6 hour hike were we started at the Riverside walk, took the horse gap trail to the side of the mountain and followed the thredbo top (something) trail to the top. At the top went a bit further to the mnt kusicko lookout and once back took the last trail back done. Total was about 24km, but amazing hike. Be sure to have water-resistant and good hiking boots if there is still some snow in the mountains. Amazing hikes and well marked paths! However at the top of the mountain there is quite some wind so be prepared. Also make sure to wear sunscreen and bring enough water and something to eat for the hike

I have always been a major ambassador for supporting local- Having lived in Los Angeles for the last 4 years working for Start Ups, I know the value of community. However, I am deeply saddened by my recent experience with Thredbo. After weeks of unanswered questions, and lack of communication from the resort. I then asked if they could honor the price I saw when my initial enquires started, and they were unwilling to comply. Sadly I can ski in NZ for a week for the price of a day at Thredbo, and knowing they turned 3 people away who would have not only supported their resort but also local bars and rental businesses. When they have runs that are muddy... Is quite devastating.

Thredbo have a "Thredbo guest service" centre.  We lost our car keys somewhere in Thredbo.  after a good samaritan handed them in,  Thredbo's Danielle Allan had them matched and returned to us in Sydney. Incredible customer focus.  Thankyou Thredbo.

Don't trust the natural snow depth on Thredbo website it is very misleading, 206cm on the website = 30/40ish cm on the runs. The snow depth measurement is taken somewhere at Snowy Hydro not at the ski resort, be prepared for some brown snow if coming in early spring.
(If I only knew this we wouldn't have gone all this way from Melbourne for a week to try something new. Vic ski resorts are with more accurate snow depth readings)

*For all drivers coming from Vic alpine side (or 8hrs from Melb with Wodonga overnight), the road is well maintained, sealed all the way but expect some 1.5hrs of no phone reception between Khancoban and Thredbo. Anticipate some fallen rocks on the road too. The avg speed between Khancoban and Thredbo is 40kmh, winding with very steep ascents and descents, takes good 1.5hrs.

Flat out lied to us to get our money. Contacted Thredbo prior to booking as we're not all skiing the rest wanted the experience of drinking hot chocolate with snow outside our cabin, making snow angels and a snowman. When we contacted Thredbo we told them the dates we wanted and asked would there be snow outside the cabin? (Otherwise we would stay in town and drive to Perisher) also is it pram accessible? Bella who booked our holiday guaranteed snow outside our cabin, also stating "that is the best time to come for snow" telling us we would be able to access cabin #25 with the baby "there's only a couple of steps" We've been here a week now it's warm with nil snow outside our cabin, there's 20-30 steps to get to our cabin, meaning we had to leave our pram in the car, parked around the corner, and the beds like a rock! Nearest snow is at the end of the runs, it's all dirty and icy as it's part of the run, it's completely unsafe to build a snow man or play with the kids there. When raising our concerns with Thredbo their response was " Oh wow she should never have told you that, we got rid of her a while ago". Thredbo offered no resolution, not caring at all, basically told us that oh well to bad she was fired a while ago so that's your problem. When we arrived we were given no info on where to pick up prepaid lift passes, there is also no info in the guest book, as check in is at 4pm (which is ridiculously late considering they still want you out by 10) by the time we figured out where to get the passes from it had closed. The next day we queued for 20 minutes to get passes, the guy serving us was hopeless we watched the rest of the line leave by the time we got the passes, as a result our daughter was late for her lesson.
Next the ski lessons, when we booked these  we were told they were each day from 9:30-12:30 however this is not the case, the lesson times vary each day. But that's not the worst part, at one point we saw the ski instructor leave our child crying as she'd fallen over while they were stopped halfway down Friday flats, her dad ski'd over to help her up, when the ski instructor saw this he started yelling at him! On another occasion we witnessed another male ski instructor yelling at, and belittling a group of kids. Katie the instructor my child had the next day was great, however I would not have my child with a male instructor again, and think the staff need some serious re educating if they're planning on calling themselves teachers.
Finally when venturing into the village almost ever second shop was closed, the atmosphere was a ghost town, when you did walk into an open store staff were too busy chatting to each other or on the phone, making the whole experience un-inviting and awkward. You'd think since the prices are way over the top compared to what you'd usually pay anywhere else, the customer service would be a little better.  I was really looking forward to a delicious hot chocolate, however when we did find somewhere that was open we were charged $8 for a dirty coffee machine hot chocolate which was the worst I've ever had, the chocolate tasted stale. As there was nothing else for the rest of the family to do we thought we would try the leisure centre as it has an heated indoor pool and a slide, my daughter loved the slide, and as we have a small child we also needed  to use the bigger pool, unfortunately yet again another let down, the pool was freezing. The only positive experience we had on this holiday was the reasonably priced fantastic food and awesome, friendly customer service from the staff and the Burger Bar. However every other aspect of the holiday was a complete disappointment, we were promised a snow holiday with a lush cabin in the snow, a bustling village and plenty to do with the kids. Im writing this review from a hot sun soaked cabin, situated in a deserted village, with overpriced everything, and rude staff! We will not be coming back. Would not recommend this place to anyone!

Overrated. Don't believe the hype.  The lifts were closed due to wind, but the report still said "all runs open". How do you get there!!! Leaving you to waste your holiday away with no courtesy buses provided or any alternatives.

It didn't matter if you bought a 2 day pass and had already used a day. It didn't matter if you had hired gear from Thredbo and needed to return it.

Instead, your weekend will be wasted and you'll have to chase your money back.

Go to Perisher instead or even take the Skitube to Perisher. Not worth the gamble when you're on holiday!

I took my family who have never ski before. We spent one week learning to ski with Group lessons and Private lessons in Thredbo.
We must say thank you to Thredbo Ski School with their professional coaches . Thanks for Lucas, Justin and Andrew for their patient and technique. Also thanks for Manu who taught my nephew Jason (Adventure Camp) for whole week.
Without their help we could not have enjoyed ourselves so much. We can highly recommend them for any beginners. It is well worth the money and We certainly will use them in future for refreshers.
We would also like to make a special  mention of Wazza our private ski lesson coach  , he certainly tried to help and encourage us and paid special attention to us. His technique was clear and concise with a very friendly attitude strongly recommended.
We will come back to Thredbo in the future .

You can get to Thredborg from Jindabyne, which is connected by a single road to two snow resorts, Thredborg and Perisher.
For some reason, there is only one road in this vast land, and it connects to two large snow resorts, so even if you leave at 7 a.m., it will take you about 3 hours to get there (sweat) Normally, it will take you about 30 minutes.
If you come to Thredbo, I recommend weekdays!

Easily the best resort in NSW - lift lines are never too bad, the run length is second to none and the village atmosphere is fantastic. Some lifts are susceptible to wind hold on windy days, so it's always worth checking the weather report before buying a ticket as these are non-refundable. If the wind is forecast for 70km/h or above, you are likely to be affected by this.

Prices continue to rise for the 2019 ski season - a single day adult ticket is now $149 ... do we have the most expensive lift tickets in the world?

This beautiful location in the Nsw Snowy Mountains, is absolutely breathtaking.
Nestled in the valley, with mountain vistas, Thredbo is a cosy alpine village with everything you could need, for your skiing/snowboarding holiday or day visit.
It's not just for skiers either.
The scenery is a photographer's dream, & I thoroughly enjoyed my week long visit recently simply spectating, taking photos, exploring & soaking up the atmosphere.
There are also many hiking tracks open out of season, & let's not forget the native wildlife. I was lucky enough to see a wombat up close, out for his/her nightly stroll one night. There were also plenty of Red Crested Robins out & about.
Accommodation is plentiful here, but be prepared to pay high prices. Look for deals & plan ahead to avoid disappointment.
When the snow's good, Thredbo has the best ski runs in Australia. Nowhere else has the vertical. There's also plenty to do in the summer months.
Extremely busy at the season time (winter). Lots of shops are available to dine. Consider renting snow equipment from somewhere else beforehand.

Thredbo is a great ski resort. Its partnership with Protect our Winters (POW) and Arnhem Land Fire Management (ALFM) takes its corporate social responsibility to a new level. By acting to reduce its greenhouse emissions and to support Indigenous communities it is taking its greatness to another level. Congratulations Thredbo, POW and ALFM. Also, last year, those many Australians who travelled to the USA to escape our local effects of climate change wasted their money. The effects in California, Colorado, Utah and Arizona in December and January were far worse than we are experiencing here. Squaw Valley and Alpine Meadows have worked out the link with climate change after a run of bad seasons and acted. It is time that we saw some corporate social responsibility from those over-sized resorts in the USA that were a massive disappointment last year. Their out of work lifties were being fed by charitable organisations!! And they are coming to Australia.
