Thredbo and Perisher refuse to acknowledge reality and move this weekend on a week or two, to a time when there is actual snow on the ground. In the seven years that I have lived in Canberra there has NEVER been natural snow on the ground in the first week of July. And to add insult to injury, Thredbo has now even refused to offer the fake snow and toboggan rides which drew families to it. Oh, and they waited until a week before the day to announce that.

So what can you expect?  At Thredbo expect zero snow, paying top dollar for ski-lifts, mechanical sled rides food and drink, a sad snow sculpture melting in the heat, empty pubs where one or two bored people watch footy, over-heated coffee shops closing early, a DJ playing house music to which toddlers and pre-teens dance while their parents stand around sipping over-priced beer and wine. The fireworks were such a non-event that we didn't even realise they had happened. At Perisher expect some man-made snow, a few better musos, but not much more. Don't expect a magical, fun-filled snow weekend as advertised in the brochures.

Don't waste your money, time and energy on this over-hyped, over-priced kids party.  Snow open weekend offers you zero snow and zero fun at full season prices. Despite the fact that Threbo and Perisher no doubt know, after so many years of having no ACTUAL snow on this weekend, that it will be snowless, they continue to promote this weekend as a funtastic opening to the snow. Too much to expect snow on a weekend claiming (and priced) to be the "start of the snowy season"? Apparently it is. Even Perisher barely has any snow at this time of the year and the reason those photos look so filled with happy people on the snow is because everyone is trying to squeeze onto the few man-made patches of snow for their instagram moment.

Until both Thredbo and Perisher start admitting that they are artificially extending the snow season in order to rake in extra money, and stop charging like there is actual snow on the ground, do yourself a favour and don't fall for their lies. Show them the contempt they deserve by boycotting them for these first two weeks of June and go when there is actual snow and you are getting what you pay for.  I for one will not be paying snow fees for a zero snow weekend again. Fool me once.....

My wife and I (70 and 71 years old) had walked the Main Range with a single night's camp west of Blue Lake. We were running late for the last lift down to Thredbo Village. Our family succeeded in getting there before the lift stopped but we, being slower, didn't make it. When the "lifty" at the bottom found out that we had been left at the top, he offered to drive up and collect us from the top, saving us a 1.5 hour, 5 km walk down. When the "lifty" arrived in the FWD to pick us up it turned out that he was Peter, the Mountain Manager. We felt so honored to be treated so well by the big boss. How kind and generous. We learned later that he had also been instrumental in organizing for our grand daughter's abrasions to be dressed when she arrived at the Village. We are very impressed with the care of the management. If this is an indication of the quality of Thredbo then we can only give it a 5 star recommendation.

I spent a few days in Thredbo last summer and discovered the Leisure Centre as I was looking for a place to go to for a swim. I got a daily pass in Thredbo that included entry to the bobsled (great fun by the way) and to the leisure centre among other things. There is a really nice multi purpose hall inside the leisure centre that can be used for lots of fun activities, like table tennis, badminton, basket ball and so on and there is a little and very well maintained pool that is just big enough for a few laps of swimming. Overall a very nice place and a great option for Thredbo visitors to be active and have some fun on a rainy day!

Mount Buller has a beautiful location and great natural views, but honestly the overall experience felt very ordinary because of the way it's managed. Like many others have mentioned, the shuttle bus driver was extremely rude and unprofessional - definitely not the way you expect to be treated as a visitor.

The infrastructure is just okay, nothing special, especially when compared to the high costs. Charging $65 entry plus $50 for chains on a clear-weather day feels more like a money-making tactic than a genuine safety requirement. For the price, you'd expect a much better experience.
Must visit in winters

Mount Buller Alpine Central is the perfect hub for anyone visiting the mountain. The facilities are well-organized and easy to access, with everything you need in one place -- from ski hire and ticketing to food, shops, and information. The staff are friendly and helpful, making the experience smooth even for first-time visitors.

It's a great spot to rest, warm up, and plan your day before heading back to the slopes. The atmosphere feels lively yet comfortable, and it really adds to the overall Mount Buller experience. Whether you're here for skiing, snowboarding, or just enjoying the alpine views, Alpine Central is an essential stop.
Very well organized, the ski coaches were good. Our family had a wonderful day.
Great place for kids and young at heart ones

I'm shocked and disgusted by the treatment my wife and I received from the shuttle bus driver on 3rd August 2025. We boarded the CS07 shuttle at around 12pm from the car park to the resort. The driver -- a tall, white man -- was unbelievably rude and aggressive for no reason at all.

When we reached the car park, my pregnant wife and I were calmly waiting to get off, and out of nowhere, the driver shouted at us in a loud, hostile tone, "Hop off, hop off!" as if we were a burden. The way he spoke was clearly filled with racist undertones -- it was offensive, humiliating, and completely uncalled for.

How does a driver working in a "hospitality" setting think it's okay to speak to guests like that, let alone yell at a woman who is clearly pregnant? He didn't ask politely, didn't show patience, didn't show basic decency. Just pure aggression, spit flying, eyes bulging -- like he owned the place. Disgusting behaviour.

He offered no assistance, no understanding, and certainly no respect. If this is the type of staff this resort hires, then it's no better than a joke. A complete disgrace to customer service and hospitality standards. We came here expecting kindness, not racism and verbal abuse.

This man should not be anywhere near a guest-facing role. He lacks training, empathy, and basic human respect. If the resort doesn't take this seriously and remove this man from his position, they will continue to lose trust, guests, and their reputation.
The bus driver was extremely racist. He literally said, 'This is our country, and you don't belong here

Absolutely disgusted with the shuttle bus service today. The driver (white male) who was operating the CS07 shuttle at 12 pm from the car park to the resort and again at 3 pm from the resort to the car park was not only rude and aggressive but also clearly racist.
We were a group heading back to the car park around 3 pm, and the bus was completely full packed shoulder to shoulder. When the bus stopped at the P4 car park, two of our group members stepped off for a moment to make space for others to get down. While they waited to reboard, a few people at the stop began getting on, and our two friends naturally stepped back in at the same time.
That's when the driver completely lost control yelling at our friends at the top of his lungs, saying "Hop off! In my country, people wait for others to get off first!" He was spitting while shouting, showing absolutely no self-control, and didn't even give anyone a chance to explain that they had only stepped off to make room for others to get down which is something respectful and considerate.
The way he singled us out, repeatedly emphasizing "my country" and "my people," made it crystal clear that his attitude was not just rude  it was racist and discriminatory. His tone and words made us feel targeted and humiliated, especially since we were from a different cultural background. Our friends were deeply embarrassed, and the entire bus was uncomfortable, but we chose not to escalate it further out of respect.
This kind of behavior is completely unacceptable, especially from someone who is supposed to be representing the resort. No one should be treated like that, and racism has absolutely no place in customer service or anywhere else

Absolutely Disgusted with the Shuttle Bus Service - Racist and Rude Driver

Our experience with the shuttle bus service at this resort was utterly appalling. On 3rd of August 2025, we took the CS07 shuttle bus at around 12pm from the car park to the resort, and again around 3pm from the resort back to the car park. The driver -- a tall, white male -- was shockingly rude, aggressive, and blatantly racist.

When the bus stopped at the P4 carpark and was already crowded, my husband and I stepped off briefly to make room for other passengers to exit. As we re-entered (since our baby was still inside the bus), the driver started screaming at us, yelling, "Hop off, hop off! In my country, what MY people do is wait for others to hop off!" Not only was this an ignorant and racist outburst, but it was also completely unnecessary. He was spitting while yelling, didn't allow us to explain ourselves, and humiliated us in front of others.

This man clearly lacks the basic training in customer service, let alone any understanding of respect, cultural awareness, or professionalism. The fact that our child was on board makes this even more distressing. No one should be treated like this, especially not guests at a resort that claims to offer hospitality.

This driver is not fit to work in a guest-facing role, and we hope the resort takes this seriously. Hire people who know how to behave with decency, or this place will quickly lose its reputation.

Utterly disgusted with the Shuttle bus service here, the driver (white guy) who drove CS07 bus today around 12pm from car park to resort and 3pm from resort to car park was extremely rude and racist. We had a group going in the bus returning from resort to the car park around 3pm, bus was so full and we were packed, when it stopped at the P4 carpark, two of our members got down to give the space for people who are about to get down. And the people were waiting there started to getting in to the bus so my two friends hopped in at the same time, then this driver went crazy screaming from top of his lungs literally shouting at my friends saying "hop off , hop off, in my country what MY people do is waiting for people to hop off  " but little he knew was my friends first hopped off from the bus just to give people space to hop down, this driver was literally spitting while shouting at us, didn't even give them a chance to explain, they were so embarrassed at the same time we didn't want to drop our class to a racist who hasn't even heard the name of manners. Please take this into consideration and this resort need to hire drivers who know how to act with manners if not at least with the basic customer service knowledge.

Booked a package with Buller Bus.  I found the booking system, calling for information and the whole package deal very easy to organize.  The coach driver was efficient and it was easy to find the coach at Southern Cross station.  The drive up to Mount Buller was very pleasant.  Going to the rental hire place was very quick and easy  having pre-booked my clothing and skis making the whole process very streamlined. The staff were very helpful but very busy so I needed to wait a little while to get some help with putting on my ski boots and taking off my gear after my ski lessons.  They have lockers available so you can go on the ski slopes relaxed knowing your gear is safe.  It's a bit of a steep walk up to the slopes, especially for beginners but I got there in time for my lesson.  Our ski instructor Christopher was excellent and very patient with the new beginners.  He gave me a lot of confidence and I felt great that I persevered for the 2 hours trying the slightly bigger slope.  It was a great experience for my first time on the snow and first time skiing.  I had plenty of time after I took off the ski gear to explore the cafes,  food outlets and gift store.  Took lots of photos and video in the snow.  Picked the perfect time to go this July because they had a heavy fluffy fall of snow days leading up to my visit.  There was a blizzard that day but it didn't deter anyone from the snow activities.  A lot of people had not been prepared with appropriate clothing and brought very young babies.  Do your research before visiting a place with snow!!  Mount Buller tours could put some hints and tips on websites for the snow tours explaining do's and don'ts and what to prepare for because honestly, some people are stupid.  I did my research and bought a pair of ski goggles, ski gloves and sunscreen just in case and I'm glad I did.  I had a nice some nice warm food and drink at the cafe and bought some gifts at the gift store.  There is plenty of time to explore a ski village before heading back to Melbourne City.  By that time I was definitely ready to get back on the bus in the warmth. I'd never experienced minus 4deg before . But overall it was a wonderful day out and for the money I paid for the package I thought it was well worth all the experiences I had, the time we were given at Mount Buller Central, All the ski hire equipment and the 2-hour lesson.  Thank you for the memories

We were really looking forward to our first snow trip at Mount Buller, but unfortunately had a very unpleasant experience with the staff. From the moment we arrived, the parking staff were extremely rude and dismissive, even though we remained polite and respectful throughout.

Mount Buller
July 15 2024
Came to the mountain to see the beautiful scenery advertised online only to find it's a $65 entry fee just to pass the gates! No concession! Got to the car park then had to catch a free shuttle bus to the village which offered nothing more than rude and entitled staff and grossly overpriced clothing and souvenirs. One jumper I looked at which looked like a Kmart knock off was priced at $556 dollars!!! Ski boots which we bought for $79 from anaconda were priced at $130! You people are MAD! A simple locker hire cost us $25 dollars. We went to the summit on another shuttle bus because we were advised by someone at the ticketing desk that one chair lift was only for people skiing and the other was $46 per person return! WHAT!!!???? We got up to the summit only to find an over priced "restaurant" with a menu you've got to use Google to search its dishes, the dish we could make sense of was a chicken parmigiana priced at $36! So we settled for a beer and a small glass of bourbon went to pay the bill to go home and were stung $30! For two drinks!!!
What REALLY made our day was getting back onto the courtesy bus! Now THAT was exciting!

The coach we went on to take us down to the car park almost careened off the side of the road hitting the sign post on the opposite side (where the huge drop is!) turning hard left to avoid going over the hill then head on into an oncoming mini bus then rammed into 5 parked cars all parked in a row mowing them down like dominoes! WOW! My husband and I were the first two people up the very front standing in the over crowded bus!
Got to our car and headed down the hill only to be stopped 3 more times due to one persons car having to be towed as they'd gone over the edge, and two others having fallen into the gutters on the side of the road!
We will be asking for our entry fee back at the very least!

During my recent visit with my young family of two adults and two kids under 5, I was completely and utterly disappointed. This place is a textbook example of a rip-off, offering absolutely no value for a visit. To just visit Mt Buller for a day, you need more than 150 AUD, and what do you get in return? Practically nothing but parking access and a sightseeing pass. The audacity of this place is mind-blowing. Vehicle entry access within the mountain costs a staggering 64 AUD per vehicle.

Want to do some sightseeing? Get ready to shell out an additional 92 AUD for a ski pass ride for two adults on a non-enclosed ski lift. And it doesn't end there. If your kids want to use a toboggan, it's another 20 AUD each, which of course, is not included in the sightseeing pass.

I don't mind paying for activities and experiences, but Mt Buller offers zero value for the exorbitant prices they charge. Save your money and take your family somewhere else where you actually get some value for what you pay.

Mount Buller is a must visit place when in winter. It was a nice experience visiting there. I visited two different month in a same year and got to experience two different vibes. When it was snowing and when it is sunny. I like both the times and enjoyed a lot. This is a must visit place if you visit Victoria in winter season.

While there were enjoyable moments, I encountered a few concerns that I believe need to be addressed for a better visitor experience.

Ticketing Staff:
The ticketing staff left me a bit disappointed. When I picked up Ski School tickets for my kids, I asked them about the assembly point, but they seemed clueless and couldn't provide the necessary information. It would be great if the staff were better informed and able to assist visitors with such queries.

Car Park Staff:
I had a not-so-pleasant encounter with the car park staff. They were a bit rude and didn't let us choose our preferred car park. It's a shame that they weren't more flexible and approachable. I understand there were many cars getting in, but they didn't need to be rude.

Slope Conditions and Safety:
The Howqua slope was a big letdown. It was icy, bumpy, and seemed like it hadn't been groomed properly. Many people were struggling and falling on their way to the Howqua chair. Unfortunately, my wife had a collision with someone, resulting in cuts on her hands. It was quite upsetting and could have been avoided if the slope had been closed or better maintained. To make matters worse, when we approached the ski patrol station, they seemed overwhelmed and too busy to provide proper care. They merely handed us a couple of bandages without even offering to help clean the cuts. It was disheartening and left us feeling neglected during a moment of distress.

Ski Lift Queue Management:
Another issue we encountered was the lack of staff to manage the queues for the ski lifts. The queues were often congested with an excessive number of people. It was disheartening to witness instances of queue jumping and abuse of the single/ski school queues. A more robust staff presence, coupled with clear guidelines and enforcement, would greatly improve the flow and fairness of the queue system.

Overall, while there were some enjoyable aspects of the time at Mt Buller Ski Resort, these concerns did impact our overall experience. I hope that the resort management takes these feedback points seriously and considers implementing improvements in staff training, customer service, slope maintenance, ski patrol responsiveness, and ski lift queue management.

A grocery shop in the village basically have everything you need, super convenient and price is reasonable. Buller is the biggest snow mountain and has plenty trails for beginners! The entire building needs a renovation. The room/carpets are filthy and stained. A friend's room had broken glass across the floor. Hallway constantly stinks of vomit, mostly because drunk patrons are throwing up wherever they find themselves. One of two places that are opened late so the place turns into a cesspool. Noise from the bar and drunk patrons in the hallways make it impossible to get any sleep. An uncomfortable stay with kids especially if you leave during the evening as you'd have to navigate drunk, vulgar teens. Even  a Mnt Buller staff member asked how we managed to get any sleep with all the noise until 3am. Basic Breakfast included in the stay, bread for toast, jam, butter some cereal and a few fruit. A joke really. You get what you pay for I suppose ... Needless to say, definitely not going back until it's demolished and rebuilt.

We had a wonderful stay at Falls Creek Alpine Resort. The chalet was warm, comfortable, and perfectly suited for a cozy alpine getaway. Everything was well maintained, with thoughtful touches that made it feel welcoming after a day on the slopes.

The location is fantastic--easy access to the lifts and village, with beautiful mountain views all around. Staff were friendly and helpful, making the whole experience smooth and enjoyable.

Highly recommend Falls Creek Alpine Resort for anyone looking for a relaxing, picturesque escape in the snow. We'll definitely be back!

falls creek was very much amazing i went there with my school and the staff- from the ski instructors to the catering staff were very nice. i have a complaint, though. the halley's lodge ski rental guy was NOT very nice to me. would not recommend going there for the rentals. he was rude to me when i dropped a ski pole and apologized. other than that, cool experience!!

Great resort for family winter holidays but some things can be improved like the poor positioning of EV chargers without any protection from blizzard conditions. The Gully car park was closed due to the heavy snowfall and preventing access to EV charging stations. Playing music in the common area in front of Slalom Plaza ski lift makes it gloomy compared to other Alpine resorts. DJ music in front of ski lift flat area will warm up the atmosphere in the late afternoons. The Last Hoot restaurant block is an eye sore for the whole ski resort experience and should be removed for opening up to fabulous views of the mountain and Halleys Comet ski run.
lovely spot.  BUT they constantly lie about ski conditions. it's beyond a joke. when they are charging $242 for a day pass they should not be allowed to lie about conditions or forecasts
Extremely friendly to snow newbies.  Particularly Lily on lifts and Jak in the board school, but really everyone.  A welcoming fun engaging atmosphere.  We will be back!

After arriving in Bright on 20 June 2025, I suffered a fractured ankle before using any part of my Falls Creek Beginner Bundle. I was hospitalised and referred for surgery in Melbourne. I immediately informed Falls Creek, providing medical certificates and hospital documents, explaining I couldn't ski this season or next.

Falls Creek offered only a voucher, which is unusable given my long recovery. Despite multiple follow-ups with full medical evidence, they have since ignored me.

By contrast, the ski gear hire company we booked with showed compassion and refunded us in full, despite similar policies.

Falls Creek's lack of response has added stress during an already difficult time. I hope they improve their customer care and treat situations like this more compassionately.
Beautiful part of the world
Victoria's premium alpine resort
Amazing place to be in winters in Victoria- Australia. Bright is another wonderful place which is near by.

We went skiing here at the end of July this year. Unfortunately, we were quite disappointed considering the very high price. There was a day of heavy rain, and for half the day they only kept a small slope open with just one ski lift operating. We asked if it was possible to get a refund or a voucher for another day, but it was completely denied. We also found the chairlifts really outdated and slow; they definitely need to be improved or at least made rainproof... for $220 you can not provide such outdated chairlifts! The slopes were poorly maintained and skiing was unpleasant due to numerous small bumps, holes, and snow piles. Additionally, the slopes were poorly marked, making it easy to get lost in low visibility. Lastly, the city slopes were ruined by the constant passage of snowmobiles! Even the restaurants on the slopes, managed by completely unmotivated staff, left us disappointed. If you don't have a phone with internet connection, you can't view the menu or place an order, and often the Wi-Fi didn't work.
Although we were there off season still great views
Very good place for a big steep down hills and beautiful views!

What a strange place is Falls Creek. After 36 years of skiing all over the world, this was my first time courtesy of the Epic pass. Definitely the snobbiest of the Victorian "Resorts". It has obviously been developed to be self serving for the elite who are members of the private lodges there. Unless you are prepared to pay for a formal sit down meal at a restaurant in the village, the lack of public areas is shocking. Well we did find the official designated "public area" (and signed as such) - a couple of dirty couches in a corner outside the toilets. Every door we opened we were confronted with a "Please Wait to be Seated" sign. Found Hoots was OK if you're happy to have a pizza and watch the beginners come down Wombats Ramble. The skiing was pretty good once you get up the top, and Cloud 9 is a decent place to have lunch or a snack (only $19 for a bowl of sweet potato chips) but no Picnics allowed (also signed in multiple languages on every pole). Thanks for dropping the entry fee by $20 before the end of August due to the absence of operating lifts, but we already got the message, and as outsiders do not feel welcome here and not likely to return 
Check out Hotham instead, we found it to be much friendlier and convenient with welcoming cafes and bars close together in the Village. And you can get the village lift there right back to the carpark!
The best snow experience in Victoria, need to well prepared. When snowing small vehicle is not enough even when wheel chain fitted.
Great place for
Quite and calm place!
Falls Creek is a great mountain, easy to get to, and with all the facilities that any person or family will need. It has well-groomed runs and with great friendly staff.

Beware of pre-booking lift tickets or lessons, if you suffer an injury no refunds will be given. They will only give you a credit that only lasts one year, which forces you to return to them next year.

I was there a couple of days ago and had a 'beginners' lesson during which we had to use a 'lazy carpet' for a few times. The lazy carpet operator was rude, she saw me loose my balance and fall during my first ever skiing class. She had to stop the carpet so that I can get back up safely, which I believe is exactly why she was paid to be there. The next time I got on the carpet during the lesson, she berated me in front of everyone in line as though I wanted to embarrass myself and fall and disregarded that it was super windy conditions alongside the snowing which affected both my vision through the goggles and overall balance (and everyone else's).

Beautiful resort perfect for skiing and snowboarding even for beginners. There are many food stops and accomodation options. Its a bit far from Melbourne though, about 5 hours. Chains are needed for the car and proper clothes.

It's pretty disappointing regarding the snow play area for the smaller kids. All Fall creek think about is how they can rip people off. $222 for a lift pass for a day. Just go overseas, and gone are the days of supporting Australian tourism.
You keep doing this to your customer, more customers will return and you will be out of business one day before you realise this

Pretty good. The snow is fair to good, but it is now starting yo slush up sightly 4/7/24 it was dry and powdery the 1st-3rd July.
Had the start of the fireworks  tonight it was a great little display, just a little difficult to navigate to if you haven't been to the village bowl before.

This is a very difficult review to leave, as our family are regular visitor to Falls and LOVE the resort. But the Resort Management have recently (a couple of weeks before school holidays!) put a total ban on venues using their transport vehicles (Cam Ams) to move to and from lifts/restaurants etc.

This has made our trip far more difficult (4 children in our party) through no fault of our magnificent venue (Astra Lodge) who will now, along with many others unfortunately have their businesses impacted by decisions outside of their control.

The aim is obviously to gauge revenues from the small businesses on the mountain and is entirely disgusting. Another case of many SME's being bullied by large corporate mismanagement.

You website is not very intuitive, I had to get the chains separately from my gear because I wanted to collect from two different places.  I booked private ski lessons for the kids, but it's not clear that the private lessons can be for kids too on the website.  We weren't sure as well whether the parents need ski passes if we are only taking the kids to lessons.  The ordering system is not intuitive: I booked group lessons first then booked ski lift passes and it added the $5 card twice and I didn't realize. Also the need for permit to get into the ski resort is not very clear, I only realised that when I stumble across another website about falls creek =_=

I tried to call to ask questions about the above and there is this one day (wednesday) where I called about 20-30 times and no one answered.  No one responded to my emails either and by the time I got through the next day, the preferred lesson time I wanted was fully booked.

However once I DID managed to get through, the customer service was extremely helpful (although ski school didn't know anything abt ski lifts rules for parents taking kids up for lessons) and got most my issues sorted.

The ski instructors are also amazing for the kids and they were skiing in no time.  So it's a bit of a hit and miss in all honesty, but it's mostly good rather than bad.
