Hotham is our favourite snow field in Australia. They have the better of the ski schools in aus as they have the big D and the kids learn to use a chair lift very early.
It's was far from a great season, but no one can control the weather.

Really easy to get around the mountain, and the drivers are so polite. Great staff makes the lines super functional. Maybe a tricky mountain for beginners, as there's limited green runs, but I had a blast in both groups and private lessons on summit

This place is truly magical, but just so expensive to visit. After paying for chains, parking, accommodation, lift hire, ski hire, food and drink...... sadly a lot of people cannot experience this amazing mountain.

This was our first snow trip and it definitely didn't disappoint. We live in Newcastle NSW and we have 3 kids aged 7,8,& 10. We visited in the last week of July. The kids did 2 days of ski lessons and 2 days of free skiing at Big D. They loved every minute and they wouldn't let us leave until the lifts stopped for the day. My wife and I did a couple of 2hr lessons which was enough for us to feel comfortable on the blue runs.
We had 40cm of snow while we were there and the runs were well groomed.
The lift staff and instructors were very helpful, (with it being our first time).
We tried 2 of the restaurants, which were great and the cafe at Big D was average but not bad.
If you get there before 9am, close parking is pretty easy to find and if U get there later the bus that runs around to the different runs is very good and has lots of stops.
We also met the amazing people at howling huskies and the kids had a dog sled ride. Most of their dogs are rescues which is cool.
The only downside is the price. We got gifted accommodation from my parents as a Christmas present at Wyndham and borrowed ski clothes for the kids from friends, but with 4 days lift passes, 2 days of lessons, ski, boot and helmet hire, park entry and snow chain hire it was about $6000, so it may be a few years before we get back.
Overall I think we have caught the bug and will definitely visit Hotham again.
One of the best snow places I ever visited.
Great place for snow adventures. Bus shuttles to travel from one point to another.

Extremely upsetting visit to Hotham recently.  As a beginner skier I was run into from behind by boarders and skiers 3 times in 2 days on the Summit run including in the middle of a private lesson and in the supposedly slow area, where many skiers seem to think it's the place to hammer down the slope.  I had boarders/skiers darting in and out close to me while I was trying to ski as if it's funny to scare beginners.  It was frightening and dangerous.  Surely Hotham Management should be patrolling the slopes to ensure the safety of all skiers and for that matter, the occupational health and safety of its own staff.
It was really disappointing that Orchard and Keoghs have been closed all season to spite having good snow coverage on the runs. I hope Hotham does something about that soon.
Since Vail Resorts took over the mountain it has become ridiculously expensive. If they could charge you for breathing the fresh air.. they would.. it's a shame, we won't be returning.

I recently had the pleasure of skiing at this resort, and let me tell you, it's a real gem! The slopes are amazing, and the staff are out of this world. Their enthusiasm and friendliness are top-notch. And here's the best part: if you're lucky, you might just catch a staff member breaking into a spontaneous dance at the ski lift. It's like they've taken "lift off" to a whole new level! If you're looking for great skiing and a bit of unexpected entertainment, this is the place to be. Kudos to the team for keeping things fun and memorable!

Sent an email to Hotham a week ago and no response.

We found Hotham not at all set up for beginners. Our basic lesson was as basic as you get - How to attach the skis and how to snow plough, then we were set loose. There were no slopes on Hotham that we felt suitable for a beginner. The "carpet" was an absolute joke, a sheer drop with no space to turn and all of the beginners in this area just fell down before they hit the barriers and likely hurt themselves. We asked some of the instructors for advice on which slopes were better for beginners and were sent to Big D carpet. When we got there we were told the only way to get to the carpet was to walk up the slopes...after a painstaking 30 minute climb we were told we couldn't be there as they had too many children then today and sent back down. As we ski'd back down the mountain - badly - An instructor pulled up with a group of children and instructed the children that we were "gerrys" and that we didn't belong on the slope!

In summary, the experience was not one that we would go out of our way to repeat and that their own instructor made comments to a group of young children about how we didn't belong there was appalling.

If you want to spend twice as much on a lift pass as you would to ski in Europe then Hotham is for you! The resort has gotten incredibly greedy over the years and not only are the lift passes extortionate but they also charge you $20 to ride the shuttle bus to the mountain from Dinner Plain, or make you pay $60 just to enter the resort in your own car (even if you are not parking and just being dropped off by a friend/family member). We have loved coming to Hotham over the years but don't intend to return - by the time you add up the costs of skiing here, you may as well put your money towards going overseas and actually having some decent snow and a bigger mountain to ski.

Mount Hotham used to be my favorite snow mountain in Australia, but not anymore. They've jacked up their lift pass price to a ridiculous $232 per day! Their management team must be dreaming. This is pure greed and completely unreasonable. You might as well go to Japan for much better snow conditions at a fraction of the cost. Shame on you, Mount Hotham!

I had an extremely disappointing experience at Hotham, and I feel compelled to share my concerns. Over two weeks ago, I reported a serious safety issue and the lack of support from Hotham staff, but I have yet to receive any communication from them. This lack of response shows a disturbing disregard for customer experiences and safety.

On Saturday, July 20th, the road conditions were hazardous due to a snowstorm, but the Hotham staff failed to provide adequate warnings or information. Despite having access to weather forecasts and real-time road reports, they only told us to use chains starting from Bay 6, without mentioning how bad the conditions really were. The visibility was less than 10 meters, the road lines were invisible, and the snow wasn't properly cleared, making driving extremely dangerous.

Our car spun 360 degrees even though we were driving at just 10 km per hour, and there were at least four accidents on the way down. When we expressed our concerns to the reception staff, they were unhelpful and suggested we check the website for accommodation, stating they couldn't assist further.

This experience indicates that Hotham prioritizes revenue over the safety and well-being of their customers. The lack of communication and support during such a dangerous situation is unacceptable. I urge future visitors to consider these safety concerns and the apparent lack of customer care before visiting Hotham.

I had also purchased a $64 day entry into my hotham prior, but was also charged another $64 to park here. The added costs to snowboard at Hotham plus the absolute pain to setup shop and park is not ideal. Just thought I would share my 2 cents on this.

Not good for small kids and adult beginners! Shame on you Hotham. You charge crazy money for lifts that we cannot go on without trying to kill ourselves on steep slopes. It is very frustrating to look at all of it and not being able to do it. Why Carpet Ride doesn't have lifts? I paid almost $500 for my kids each to walk up that hill!? Why Carpet Ride is not open for everyone to practise on before 12 and after 3? it would have been an amazing little hill to practice the skills!

It is Affordable, great thing is kids can enjoy there. The area is near to dinner plain. The day we went there was sunny and my kids  even took their gloves and jackets off that day, they enjoyed a lot. We will go next year again over their.

This would be an easy 4 star if not for the crazy prices. If you book a ski pass same day it's 220+ just for an adult ski pass. If you book in advance online it drops to 170. In Chamonix you go to the tallest Mountain in Europe for 60eu and access 4 countries.... A similar sized ski system in Scotland - Glencoe which also has very average snowfall is a 30 gbp price. I cant reconsile these prices. They are just insane. The ski region is nice enough. It's largeish and has some variety. Good access to the back country. It's better than Buller by far and the infrastructure is better. Pulling the price down to something that isn't at the same level as heli skiing might see them with a higher rating. I'd says it's one of your safest places to actually get snow in Oz if you time it well. But you may be better off flying to Japan to save your money. If money doesn't matter to you at all, then it's a good spot to ski in Oz. Shout out to the amazing friendly staff though. Informative - happy - stoked on life. You all rock.

Guys, this place is NOT for adult beginners.

We did some investigation prior to booking and were told by staff that Hotham is great for adult beginners, but it's definitely not.

The bottom of the summit run (where all adult lessons are held) is also where the run concludes, so experienced skiers are ZOOMING past you, and get impatient if you're in their way.

The area where you're learning is FULL of people learning, and also a thoroughfare for people ending the summit run, starting the summit run, and using both the chairlift and pommer. It's SO BUSY!

No room to learn properly, and our instructors kept getting bored and wanting to take us up the summit run, which is NOT appropriate for a fresh, super-beginner person.

Everyone who is learning is walking on top of one another. It's not a fun place to learn, and doesn't have enough green runs to accommodate all the beginners.

If you're an adult beginner, this is NOT the place for you.

Also, it's super, super, SUPER expensive. No half-day lift passes. Expensive lessons with (mostly) underexperienced, unmotivated instructors.

Overall a great resort, we had a alot of fun skiing and enjoying the absolutely breathtaking views from the summit. The only reason I've given 3 stars is because the staff at one of the restaurants we went to was racist as he was very rude with his attitude towards us only to be friendly with other customers. Apart from this minor setback, overall a great place to visit.

We arrived there under blizzard conditions and the road was a bit chaotic because it was snowing and icy. We brought chains but our car is 4x4 do we didn't use and it was fine to go up the mountain. The first days was very cloudy and with poor visibility but the last 2 days the sun came up and it was beautiful. The snow was in good condition considering it was the end of August. In the sunny days the runs were a bit icy but overall in good condition. There is lots of blue and black runs and some bits through the trees. There is a bit of lines in the lifts but nothing bad. Lots of restaurants with ordinary food, nothing fancy but good.
Kids club is the best part my 4 year old had lots of fun ...I hope next year the day care for babies is open too so then we can come back.
Its really an amazing place the drive to the top juat takes your breath away ..

Extremely overcrowded to the point of being unsafe, limited grooming making some runs unskiable, not opening a major lift, exorbatent resort entry fees, outdated and dilapdated facilities.

Its a beautiful place and the staff are great but not grooming half the runs, not opening Blue Ribbon lift and charging 335 dollars just to enter the resort made me decide never to go back. Not to mention the main lift is nearly thirty years old and there has been no new lift infrastructure put in since the nineties.

Go to a resort that actually cares about their customers because this place is an overcrowded, dilapidated, expensive hell hole.
Breathtaking view, booking and entry fee are required if parking in resort. Use free bus service to move around.
With recent superb falls, it is a winter wonderland. Staff were extremely helpful and friendly.

What an amazing resort! The slopes are sensational and well maintained. The restaurant, bars and other services are really good. The staff were supper helpful and all polite. The drive up is an experience, make sure you have you have or hire snow chains as it can get wild at times. Definitely a place to visit and we'll be coming back very soon. Cheers Hotham

Car parking is limited. 2 really good days. Last day was disappointing not because of the weather (overcast & windy) but more to do with only 2 lifts operating - therefore everyone was funnelled into these runs - therefore lots of lift staff were available. I counted 6 staff on one chair lift loading area. However I did not see anyone actually doing anything to organise groups of "four". At times the chair lift stopped as there were only groups of 2. The lift was already slow due to wind. It was a bit of a farce considering time, lift cost etc.

Could have better safety precautions- there is a cliff where the beginner lessons are conducted and I saw 2 people nearly fall backwards down it because the only precaution was a cloth fence with a large gap at the bottom.
There aren't enough poles with lights as you drive down the mountain in the snow, especially when the visibility is no more than a couple of metres ahead. Signage about snow chains not being needed was wrong at one point as well.

If you drive up the mountain you'll have to pay a vehicle entry free of $56-$62 per day.
Nice place
Had my first ski lesson there. The location was super nice and the lesson was great. The only down side is you have to buy the ski lift pass even if you use it or not to get the lesson.

Australia has only a few snow skiing resorts and Hotham is one of them. Very beautiful. Road to the top is double lane and has multiple chain points on the way. Snow slopes and lifts are just in front of main road and hotham central, where you can hire gears and eat/drink. Car parking is limited near hotham central so you may find a spot 2 kms further down the road. There are shuttle buses to take you from your car parking to the hotham central. There are multiple slopes and lifts to suit every level. I am a beginner so took a 2 hour skiing lesson in a group of seven. Accommodation at the top is limited and therefore quite expensive; you need to book in well advance. I stayed at the bottom in Bright. Renting gears, food and lift pass are expensive. But this maybe because of short snow season in Australia.

Mount Hotham is one of Australia's major ski resorts, located in the Victorian Alps of the Great Dividing Range, in the Australian state of Victoria. The mountain is located approximately 357 kilometres north east of Melbourne, 746 kilometres from Sydney, and 997 kilometres from Adelaide by road

What a brilliant resort. We couldn't stay long this time as we were headed from Sydney to Melbourne. But we will be back. This resort is absolutely fantastic. Many hire and dining options, we went into the Hotel and they had Mulled wine which was perfect. The parmigiana and schnitzel were both great and the mustard dresses salad! Yum. The toboggan play area was perfect for the littlies. The drive up is breathtaking. We were so fortunate to have the weather changing with cloud, clear and snow within a few short hours giving us spectacular views and experience.
The slopes we saw were nice wide and long and there was plenty of snow. Drive out the otherside on the Great Alpine road for a truly unforgettable experience, just take it very easy and bring chains in case. We also saw the XTrail we were following almost run into the embankment & they weren't going fast. The resort and drive was like you're being transported into another world, perhaps Europe.

This climb is an absolute giant in the world of Australian cycling. 30.8 kilometres, this is the distance of Mt Hotham making it one of the biggest climbs Down Under distance wise, but the Col takes out the top spot in elevation gain being the highest paved climb in Australia. The road snakes around in a massive U shape, so at almost all times you can see the elusive  distance summit and it daunts you on how huge this mountain really is (but trust me it's worth the exertion to see those views!). There are two eminent steep sections of this big hill the first of the pair being The Meg: The Meg swims on to scene at five kilometres in with an average grade of about 8% maxing out at about 14%, nothing to deep just make sure you know your strokes! CRB hill: This section lasts for precisely 1.57 kilometres at an average gradient of 8.8%. Hopefully by now your in to a good rhythm knowing the finish is almost in your grasp, dancing on the pedals like Tadej Pogacar, but if not your in for a tough one. The views of this mountain are absolutely stunning from bottom to top, it's a beautiful part of the world. It is hard to beat this mountain, cycling heaven, ski resort, accommodation and cafes what more could you ask for 1857 meters in the air.
The Victorian Alps are a great holiday all year round! Loved every minute of my latest holiday

We still belived them that they did not open the summit T bar because of low snow in those area. But when i checked yesterday, i found that they closed the Hut run and opened the summit T bar despite they did not even get 1cm of Snow.  So what i can see from this is , they lied to us about the snow level and wanted to keep the Summit T bar trails from not getting used while the Hut run was ok to use.

Mount Baw Baw - Disappointing and Unsafe Toboggan Experience

We recently visited Mount Baw Baw with high expectations for a fun family day in the snow, but our experience with the toboggan area was extremely disappointing and raised several safety concerns.

Firstly, the toboggan area is simply not safe for tobogganing. The entire section is very slippery, including the top starting area. There's no leveled surface to properly prepare before you start the ride, which makes it too easy to slip and fall even before getting on the toboggan.

Once you're on the sliding path, things don't get any better. The toboggan run is full of big holes and bumps, which makes the ride not only uncomfortable but genuinely dangerous. With so many people using the slope at once, there's a serious risk that someone could come down too fast and crash into those in front, causing injuries. We saw this nearly happen multiple times and it was honestly stressful.

Unfortunately, the management of the crowd and facilities left a lot to be desired. When it gets busy (which it usually is during the season), the whole place feels chaotic and poorly managed. There isn't enough staff supervising, and the safety rules don't seem to be enforced at all.

One of the serious downsides is that there's only one ambulance onsite for the whole mountain, which isn't comforting given how many people are there and the level of risk on the toboggan run.

It's also frustrating considering how much it costs--$67 just for entry, plus $20 extra for every person over age 4 to use the toboggan area. With these high prices, you'd expect much better safety measures and organisation from the management.

I do want to mention that the emergency response team on site were clearly trying their best with the resources they had, but they seemed overstretched due to the lack of support and planning.

Overall, I definitely can't recommend the toboggan area at Mount Baw Baw, especially for families with young kids. If safety and good management are your priorities (as they should be!), you're better off looking elsewhere until they make some much-needed improvements.
Beeeeautiful spot! Bit pricey, and absolutely chockers on weekends but that's expected. Staff were bloody ripper and very helpful

The most disappointing attempt at visiting the snow. We organised to go with our 2 year old to take her to the snow for the first time and instead of happy memories, we left with frustration and a very upset toddler. We arrived at 10am and were instructed by a staff member at the gate that all the parking had run out if we hadn't pre-purchased. We were instructed we could park along the main road and take a shuttle bus to enter the resort. Not ideal but accepted that was the outcome of not realising we needed to book ahead of time. We then parked around 200m down the road as by then a large number of cars were also needing to do the same. We started lining up and another staff member was working her way down the line for people to pay their entrance fee. She informed us it was $67 for the car load plus $10 per person for the shuttle bus. A total of $87 for me, my husband and our toddler. While I think this was still a bit steep for entry, I can justify the price IF that actually included parking INSIDE the resort. But no, this was charged for parking along the main road alongside entry which we still had to wait for a shuttle bus for.

We copped the cost and thought it is what it is but thought it was an absolute rort. We ended up lining up for over 45 minutes and in that time 2 buses collected people. These buses could only fit 10 people at a time so in the 45 minutes we were waiting for, we still had at least 25-30 people ahead of us. And each return trip for the buses seemed to take a minimum of 25 minutes.

In the end, with a toddler who had absolutely had enough and 2 very disappointed adults, we asked for a refund which was accepted (thankfully) and decided to leave and visit a different snow field a different day.

We visited Mt Baw Baw 8 years ago and had a pleasant experience then but after today, I can safely say we will not be attempting to visit anytime soon as the shuttle bus system and exorbitant entrance fees when the car ISN'T EVEN PARKED INSIDE THE RESORT left us extremely disappointed and frustrated at the way Mt Baw Baw manages its guests.

I understand it is a weekend in snow season but management need to have a good look a their systems as this was a terrible experience.

We drove to there on Saturday but was told to leave due to the extremely long queue of cars and the people prepaid already inside when we were in the queue, didn't impact our mood actually. Drove up again on Sunday morning with prepaid everything, lucky not a crazy busy time and only 10mins we were in. Getting rented equipments gave us a bit of headaches due to the queue again, but all in suggested time anyway.
Lucky the snow was great, nice instructors, easy access to everything. Good place for beginners, kids took the 2hr lesson and directly flew themselves, very impressive. We love this place.
I know some people had bad experiences or made low grade comments here, but as long as you understand the chain is compulsory and forced, and the natural snow is controlled by weather, you should bring everything you need with a heart full of longing to enjoy your trip, at least the staff we met and saw there were very friendly and responsible, just a couple of restaurant employees we experienced were a bit of...

This image captures a serene winter landscape, likely in a mountainous or high-altitude region. The foreground is dominated by a blanket of pristine white snow, with delicate blades of grass poking through, each one encrusted with sparkling frost, creating a beautiful, intricate texture. The low angle of the shot emphasizes the close-up detail of these icy formations.

In the midground and background, the sun is either rising or setting, casting a warm, golden glow across the horizon and filtering through the sparse trees, which appear to be covered in snow or frost themselves. The sky transitions from a soft blue directly overhead to hues of orange and yellow near the sun, with wispy clouds adding to the ethereal atmosphere. The overall impression is one of crisp, cold beauty, tranquility, and the quiet magic of a snowy morning or evening.

2-2:30 hours from  Melbourne- Tyre Snow chains must be carried and used when instructed during winter months (can be pre-arranged and hired from Noojee/Icy Creek/Tanjil Bren)
As is lower altitude mountain compared to others in Vic, weather /snow conditions can be variable - plan accordingly and continue to respect the cold weather impact to health.

DO NOT GO.  $20 for tobogganing pass... for 1.5hrs!!!!   and it doesn't include rental.  half day (2 sessions) inc. hire close to $200 for 3 kids.  unbelievable!   it's August, it's 10 degrees, there is hardly any snow in the toboggan park.  Shame on you for charging so much for kids activity.

Also $64 for mountain entry then only 500m of road to the carpark!  outrageous. Same cost as Mt Buller and Hotham but the road there is much longer and resorts much higher and they provide something for the money at least ie. shuttle buses etc.   Baw Baw just provides you with kick to the wallet.

We wer there with kids and this was the first time. Was a great fun with kids. Very nice atmosphere, not too crowded like Mount Buller. Lot of waking trails filled with snow, where you could go and have fun. Rent toboggans else where much cheaper.

I went to Mount Baw Baw to practice my snowboarding and it was horrible because I could not get a lift to the top, since they did not have a proper ski lift. I don't understand why they would not have this basic facility at a snow resort. I wasted a whole day and a good amount of money for nothing. I had to walk as far as I could to the top and then just get a slide down. I'm really disappointed. I do not recommend Mount Baw Baw at all.

2 and half hours from the city towards the south east of Victoria, my Baw Baw is the nearest snow resort for for Victorian
Not a the biggest in Victoria but it has what you need for a snow day
It could get really busy during holiday and weekend, so make sure you book online for a quick entry at gate also rent a car chain before you get there otherwise you will be scammed by $49 even if it's sunny
There's different section for board and skiing and small section for Toboggan, which a $20 entry
Plenty parking sports, but make sure you don't park on the icy ground if you don't have a four wheel drive.

Nearby touristic suburbs like icy creek and noojee if you wanna have a night in a village, and save your self a 3 hours drive if you coming from the  side of town

We went there 4 families with kids on 31st Aug 2024 and it turn out to be disaster, first thing we bought 11 toboggans area tickets it was for 1:45 hours $20 each, but the area was filled with 1.5 feet of soft snow and they did not even try to compact it or not even mention when we bought tickets. I went back and complained and they told us you can complaint but no help whatsoever. I registered the complaint it's almost 8 days no reply or call at all.
On the way back coming down we had accident one of our family car lost traction and lost control and due to loose snow which they fitted there snap the brake line and lost brakes, luckily family was ok but one of their staff who scraps snow on the road with truck ask us to move car  even there was no brakes on car and car lost control again and hit other side of the curb towards hill side, luckily car stopped due to snow on side otherwise I would end up in the down hill with car.
The management is really bad and don't expect any help if anything happens there.
I would never go there or tell anyone to go there now onwards.
Beautiful part of the world

Took my sons - one came over from WA and have never seen snow. Was awesome. Sally there is no ability to get up to the top of Mt Baw Baw unless you ski and I am a bit old for that and walking - would be nice to have a lift for non-ski ppl
Loved every moment at Mt Baw Baw
One of the best places I wish to go whenever possible.
Great

Resort is decent and there was excellent snow on Sat July 20.. but management is pathetic..had to wait 3 hours for snow chain fitting..3 hours absolutely inside the car was an ordeal we will never forget( we were just 500 metres away from the snow chain fitting place at Baw Baw and it was around 1030am) .Could only reach the resort at around 3 pm.I even paid  entry day fees of 64$ online but what's the use
So relaxing
Drive straight to the resort and very convenient.

Expensive!
Have to pay $64 to enter the snow area. Beside that they charge $49 for snow chain for a small portion of road on top, when there is no snow on the road anyway because it's cleaned with trucks and they know you will not use it. Carpark worker was rude and ignorant. If you don't like working in cold go work somewhere else!
watch the video, approximate cost with car, skis, clothes, food 250 dollars to 300 dollars per person.

The customer service was great. We had ski lessons with this instructor, Henry, and he was amazing. He taught us really well. He totally deserves an A+. But it was a bit expensive, so I have to take one star off.

Disgusting attitude from your staff this past weekend when I was part of a group visiting the mountain. If you can't speak to and treat your customers in a better manner, perhaps you should seek another job where you are not dealing with the general public.

I don't know why you have to pay $64 to get up the mountain! in Europe access to the mountains is free, rethink that and you might have more visitors!!!
we were lucky we had snow. Add $20 per person to access the toboggan run and $20 to rent a toboggan for 1.45 hours.
One run open out of two and magic carpet not working! A total rip off! If you are in the area and you want to see snow but do not ski try Mount St Gwinear it's free.

Was great family day out! Expensive? Yes! Shame the magic carpet for kids wasn't working, and we still had to pay $20 per head to use the tabaggon run. Couldn't understand why.. overall, the whole family loved it, but make sure to have alot of funds in the account

had an awesome time and pete at the ski hire was an absolute delight. however when returning snow pants i had accidentally left my phone in pocket and before i realised it was too late and they went into the wash so my phone is now broken unable to fix it, it is my fault but maybe in future before washing rental clothes please check the pockets for belongings for other people so this doesnt happen again.
Very educational
Too pretty, easy hike and wonderful weather
Big hill
Good views and all round a nice place to visit in both summer and winter.
I enjoyed riding my motorbike to this village. Unfortunately, it was summer and the 1 cafe was not open. The place was void of activity but it is worth a visit
Good coffee and I had a great lunch
Would be good to see in the snow!
not much snow during most times

So much snow this weekend thanks to a huge fall on Friday. No crowds and lots of fun for kids and adults. No lifts running or ski hire on the mountain. But there's still hot food and drinks at the village.
Fantastic experience loved it, if timed right it's a great place for the family to spend hours doing activities or a casual stole around.

Got there a bit late (September first week) so no snow except some artificial stuff that covers max 2 sizes of football pitches area. But, good enough for kids to have fun, although not for adults. Totally agree with the entrance fee for park maintenance and essential services.

But it was super sunny, still had to pay for chains just to put them inside the boot during the entire day. It is okay for safety, but it would be super practical if they provide hire service at the entrance down there on snow days or possible weathers and also village park on sunny days in case of weather changes without making it compulsory to rent it at the entrance gate everyday. So people do not feel bad or unnecessary fees to enjoy the park.

We wanted to hit the highway asap and choose  the other side/ South Face Road and enjoy that part of the road as well. That was the worst idea of the trip, as the entire road is really not suitable for even AWD with all weather tyres as the whole road is filled with mortars and not carpeted/ sealed upto Thomson Valley Rd all the way. Honestly, not worthy to check the whole other side whatever it shows on the map. Go back through the Baw Baw Tourist Rd even though it is longer.

Cheers...
Great experience as an introduction to ski resorts with small kids.

I love this place - an excellent get away.. Gets busy and exciting.. And offers lovely outdoor experiences - recent trip was with limited snow but this offered excellent bushwalks on tracks that I as child wld ski by cross country skiing

One or 2 runs were avtive while I was there and downhill skiiers and snowbowrders were enjoying it, also the tobogoning run was getting regular use - lots of fun

When you're out in snow use common sense, good planning and look after yourself and others in your group.

The accommodation we stayed at was superb

Fantastic day out and well worth the drive from Melbourne. Very easy access to parking and toboggan area for the kids :-).  Cross country skiing and downhill are available.  There are two main eating shops and bbq and warm eating area.
Really disappointed, no real weather condition mentioned in the website, there was no snow at all and you must need chain... just pay for everything but no service at all
Ripped off $62 for entry per car. Had to pay $39 for chains and there was no snow or ice on the road
Good Place for family

Very difficult drive up the mountain. Roads need to be improved considering the amount of money and revenue that this place generates and Parks Victoria does not seem to want to spend the time nor money to improve the roads.
Works should be carried out in off season.?????

Little bit disappointing, snow was very minimal.

Website said it had snowed 20cm but hadn't actually snowed just the fake stuff, you also have to pay for EVERYTHING, they don't even check that you have tickets for the lifts so it doesn't even matter in the end. After being there for a few hours all there fake snow had disappeared and they weren't adding more so it made snow boarding kinda painful if you fall over a lot, all the other years I've been here it's been wonderful and it is out of peak atm but they could charge less for some things and let you know in the website weather it's actual snow of just fake stuff

So disappointed with a trip to Baw Baw. Althought I can sympathise with their lack of control on the snow coverage, the $89 lift pass when there was only  1 T Bar open and so little snow that my family walked up to the top of the 100m snow run is appalling. The booking system is confusing also. I assumed due to having to book a day that my ticket would be void if I did not go, regardless of the snow cover, so we went anyway. I however think a discounted ski pass or free ski pass when you have paid the $55 just to enter the resort would be justified if in fact the lift wasn't even needed. I hate to think the amount of revenue you raised out of today, as there was only 20 passes left for the day. Very upsetting and dissapointing, and simply dangerous to have that many people on one 100m run.
One of the best place  entertainment for kids and families ..
Excellent

The day we went there was not much snow around but there was still enough for toboggans, skiing and snowboarding.
It is a beautiful place that has many carparks and helpful staff. Very popular resort as its not too far from Melbourne.
Great place to visit for the day.  About 2.5 hours by car from Melbourne
Great place
Decent place to visit to see the snow. The resort is not well equipped as Buller or Hotham.
Terrible experience! ruined my day! $58 entry fee, $ 85 lift and $ 35 ski rent. You have to spend $39 for chain, even no snow and 4 wheel! No Snow!!!, Don't go there, and never go there ago.

I don't like it at all..
Even though there was  less snow the tabbogan area was not maintained.
Also the ticket of tabbogan area bit expensive compare to other mountains.
There were no wide range of free activities everything have tickets and pre booking required..
Good  experience
Very beautiful. There are skis for rent. Beautiful snow.

Our family was at Mt BawBaw yesterday. What a terrible trip after years of not visiting. I can't believe everything is so bad now, from high entrance fee, weak management, poor service. It took me almost 3 hours to get there and my kids only had 1 hour for playing toboggan and then had to come back because it was late. Dont go to Mt Bawbaw, it just ruins your day. Never comeback
One of nicest Alpine areas in south East of Melbourne

We had extremely bad experience with Mt Baw Baw services. Really poor management during this peak season. We had to wait for 3 hours just to get the ticket and the wheel chains to be able to go to the mountain. Although we drove the 4WD, we still had to wait for more than 1 hour just to get the wheel chains to carry it in the car. We asked if we can get it and and go without going the the fitting line but they refused as others already waited. They should have priority line for those only need to carry the chains without fitting to drive through. I felt so bad for the staff working at the fitting station as they were only 2 but have to fit hundreds of cars all day. They looked extremely tired. Needless to say, the pass is $62/day for nothing, we still need to pay extra for the services such as toboggan. We hired the toboggan but playing outside of the toboggan park because it was too crowded in there and I felt it wasn't safe for young kids. Then they came and said we were not allow to play there without any signs saying so just because we didn't pay for the toboggan park tickets. The toilets were over crowded and super dirty. The hot tap water in the abundant toilet was broken, my two year old and I had to wash hands with cold water only in the middle of the snow rain outside. What an experience! We wouldn't recommend Mt Baw Baw and wouldn't come back next year!

Terrible Management, hundreds of cars waiting for taking snow chains or fitting chains...Only 2 workers...Most of customers waiting 2-3 hours waiting in car with the kids screaming.
This is the first time I came back here after covid period, They charged everything, everything is expensive with a terrible service....toilets are super dirty and smelly...They charged everything and give you the worse service....We wont come back ever again...and dont bother to go to mt baw baw...it would give you stress and tireness only.

After reply from the resort: They still dont see the poor traffic management and sevices.
We were advised we didnt need to fit the snow chains as our group have 4 4x4 drive cars. Why would you keep all of 4x4 waiting in the fitting bays instead of just giving them chain and keep going? so it would fasten the waiting line.  Plus poor signages....thats why were hundred of cars waiting for the non sense stuff.
Not much snow, entry fee and Tobogan service fee charge ($63 and $12 ), felt Ripped off. View was beautiful. Don't follow road sign saying 80 , just do 30 to 35, if anyone want to return home safely.
Great place.
Wonderful experience. All the staff was really helpful, this was our first trip. Really loved it.
Excellent staff and friendly. Relaxed atmosphere.
Had a good fun experience with the family and enjoyed the nature. The food was good but bit pricey for the pizza   that we ordered but still was good.
Nice
Nice cafe with great views. Feels deserved after a great climb on the bike.
Such a great place for the Australian Tarmac Rally. Friendly staff, good food, and great facilities.
Great view and friendly staff. Service was great
It has a wonderful disc golf course. Go play it in the summer months!!
Nice summer hike
Winter or summer is the easiest way to get up a mountain and enjoy the wiew.
Lilies in guest services was so friendly and very helpful she is a credit to your company well done.
Great place for four-wheel driving
Beautiful location year round
Amazing during the snow season
A great place to stay over the winter. Plenty of snow activities and some OK places to eat at. Depends on snow cover and weather
View from Baw Baw Village

Fun experience but very expensive.
Cafe had nice chips but again crazy pricing!
Wish there was a bit more space that you could sit around and build snowmen or have snowball fights, very crowded small space.

Look it's not Mt Buller or Mt Hotham but it's not trying to be either. Good fun little mountain that the whole family can enjoy. Kids learning to ride is the main target market here but parents can have some fun as well.
Staff were exceptional!!!

It's a nice area, has Alpine dingo enclosure.
Bit pricey.

This resort has gone downhill big time over the years. A group of us buy a season pass every year, but this year we have barely gone up cause half the mountain has been closed most of the season. And now we are into spring they are only opening 1 run yet they have coverage over all the runs?

I don't understand what their business strategy is, but keeping 80% of the runs closed for a majority of the season isn't going to entice people to visit & spend money.

Unfortunately come next season, will be the first year in a long time we won't be taking up a season pass. It's just not worth your money to be able to use it so little.

We normally make 10-15 trips up per season, this year we have made 5. Would have been cheaper for us to just buy day passes each time.

Such a shame cause while this resort is small in comparison to the other big mountains, Baw Baws runs have personality & while short, lots of fun. (When more than 1 run is open)
Good place

Seems be better this year, probably because of the heavy snow. Does get packed. Food options are simple and gets packed during peak hour, kinda pricey and fairly average but to be expected. Get in early to avoid 2wd cars with chains. No issues climbing up the hill with the 80 series. Worth a visit.

It was a disappointing experience as there was some confusion with the toboggan run. We bought magic carpet lift for the family only to find the Frosti Frog run was closed. Contacted the management and were told it was opened but on the other side. We missed the fine print when purchasing the pass thinking the barcode was the ticket, which we should have gone to the office to exchange for tag. Even so, the distance to the opened toboggan run was actually 3x walking distance of Frosti Frog. Carrying 5 toboggan with impatient kids doesn't help. Suggested to them to make a sign for the opened toboggan run instead.
Mt Baw Baw only had T-Bar, no lift. There are place to rent all your equipments in the village too. Perfect place for those who seek to do some low budget day trip or Ski.
Nice place to be , i would suggest to stay in the resort.. and take part in snow activities.
Great family skiing at an affordable price. Great fun and great runs for the average skiers.
Kids had a great time sliding along the mountains.
Very nice experience coming here. The people are lovely and helpful . Perfect for beginners.
Good place for someone wanted to learn ski and snowboarding. If you looking for more extreme or challenging hill, this is not recommended.
Beautiful and close to melbourne
Amazing experience
Tobogganing area very small. Signage in main carpark could be better.
Great resort, however, need some renovation on a lot of thing
It is a nice place for those who are into skiing and snow boarding. Not much to do for the rest though. Tabogganing facility is rather small and boring.
Great day

The best snow resort I've been. More activities, bigger and wide area, well organised, thick snow, even parking is very smooth and people are very nice and friendly.
Suggest book everything in advance and online.  Weekend there's a live band during the day. Be careful in the road always.
An amazing place. Suitable for families as well as semi professional skiers. Excellent trekking routes.

One of the nearest snow mountains from Melbourne city, which is around 3 hours drive. When we reached there, we got some fresh snows from morning but not snowing then. Good place to spend a day doing skiing , tobogganing and enjoying snows. This place is relatively small compare to Buller. But if you are visiting during the peak winter, it is recommended that you wear some warm clothes, snow boots and hand gloves. You can hire them from here as well, there are enough if them here. Normal shoes are slippery to walk in the snow. There are good restaurants, you can sit there and warm your selves having some pizza, coffee etc. If you are driving to the mountain, make sure you carry the snow chains for your vehicle, you can hire them at the gate. It is mandatory to carry one during winter, but needs to wear it only if it snows and roads are slippery. Only last few kilometres, may be around 3 to 4km has risk of snows, but mostly they clear the snow from the road. There is enough car parking at the mountain top, but if it is filled, you have to park it at the gate and take the shuttle bus service.
Perfect for a day trip
Great place for a day visit, micj cheaper than other sking places.
Tobogganing is ok but to short and needed bigger runs for bigger kids,
Nice place for fun in winter during school holidays.
Wonderful time at Du Nord Lodge. Can't wait to return.

Great day out with the family. 1st time taking our 7 year old son. Loved Tobogganing! Food a bit expensive tho and our coffee wasnt piping hot but a great day anyway. Park at carpark 1 which is the closest to the resort if you can!
Too small. Too crowded. The lift is shabby. Too dangerous for beginners. The service overall is terrible.

Nice Drive to hit the destination. Be careful with woods & broken branches interfering the road. A small coffee shop serves good coffee on the way at 1.5 hour drive before the top. Unsure why $60 fee to enter the resort which really doesn't serve any special additional service except parking. Snow chain they says mandatory, I took it but didn't needed to use them. Cafe restaurant up there serves good food, coffee was so ok... good spot for toboggan & , however not a huge area as mount Hotham.
A lot of fun and a lot of space to enjoy the snow the only issues is none of the places said that they have atms or that they can withdraw cash so take it with you!
Middle of June 2022, was raining consistently foggy and come, but still enjoyed ourselves.
Good place but the road leading to mountain is not good it has fallen trees
It's amazing place. Combination of natural beauty and snow. Easy to excess from Melbourne. Good place for recreation for all age people

I pre booked for the Queen's birthday Sunday but when we got to the resort around 2pm we had to wait in the car another hour to find out that there was no room. Will go to lake mountain next time as they limit the number of people before you travel.
Good place for snow experience. But not much hotels to stay.
Wonderful place if you love snow you should visit this resort. But must carry water proof shoes and some warm jackets
Great experience with the family. Easy to access, helpful people, great views, awesome service, restful experience and the best of all - lots of snow to play and enjoy! A must visit for all!
Great place to visit. Snow was amazing.
For the start of the season it was great . All the staff were friendly and fantastic. There was a bit of snow
A great place for a pre-winter walk.
Snow already at mt baw baw
Beautiful spot. Had nice coffee and walk around.

I lv ridding the bike up here motorcycle that is. There's a nice restaurant to have a  coffee  or a nice meal the views are good but they need to trim back the trees at the restaurant they spiol the view. It takes around 2 hours from eastern suburbs to get up there but it's thick bush fantastic views from Noojee on wards and don't forget to check out the Toorongo  Falls  just out of Noojee
Great place and food and start thanks

For cyclists this this is more than a mountain, it's a savage monster. This is by far the toughest hill in Australia, and I wouldn't be exaggerating to much to say in the entire world! No reprieve from constant gradients of above the double digits for more than 5 kilometres! But don't get me wrong this is also one of my favourites. When you step of the bike at the top, panting like a dog on a 40 degree day, take in the the beautiful scenery and sit down at the amazing cafe, it all becomes worth it. I dare you to take the plunge in to the hardest climb Down Under.

This whole mountain is so very poorly managed, which is a shame. Would never recommend for skiing/boarding - even for learners the stupid outdated lift systems are super challenging and do nothing to help people actually learn snowsports.

EDIT 30/1/22: The response form management, 3 years later shows how little they actually care about customer feedback. And no, T-Bars and Poma are not widely used around the world...at least not at real resorts that have invested in new infrastructure at some point over the last 50 years. There's not even a single actual chair lift at this pimple of a mountain. If you want to learn head to Buller where they have actual lifts and beginner hills steep enough to actually gain some momentum.
One of the best snow destination

We went there during the summer, but it was raining. The mountain itself is amazing, really thick bushy forest. Was happy to see nature this way. We saw wallabies, geese, tons of rosellas. During the winter, the resort seems to be a money making machine. You have to pay like 30 dollars a car just to enter the mountain. Although they do have a dingoes in captivity and there were a really interesting sight. Bet it is fun to ski here but pricey.
Great place to visit in summer, hiking, mountain biking, trampolines or just checking out the wildflowers. Winter time it's a great mountain for beginners
It was cold even in summer, great coffe places and hiking opportunity.
The only half lift worked and they charged full price. Redicilus!!!

Sadly not much snow but still a pretty place to visit
Lovely lunch overlooking beautiful outlook
Coming back for the Frisbee golf???
Short 50m man made runs
Loved it!
Lovely
Friendly staff
Excellent for a day trip
Called 5 times no answer on phone need more staff.
Beware, school holidays - super busy for a little snow...Must Prebook though - especially, if you need toboggans. The traffic horrendous, took us greater than 1hr to queue before getting into resort.

Overall good!

But...1.5 hour wait for a table in the only restaurant open on the mountain and during school holidays???
Their ski  and tobaggoning facilities are good. I recommend.

Our visit was probably too early in the season so no snow other than the man made ones. Still enough to get some activities done. Toboggan slide was fun for kids. As a first time visitor had to hunt for information. They need to have some kind of information kit for visitors.
Fantastic day with my Granddaughters
Boyah, gotta love Baw Baw
Fun place to play disc golf.
The first choice for beginners
There was no snow, I think they should post daily updates
A nice place to be super awesome views
Great place for snow play. Very expensive however.
Amazing, lots of fun
Lovely location and place lots of fun
Awesome drives, scenery and veiws to get to the summit! The cafe and facilities are a great place to visit!
Good ride, good food, incredible views
Helpful
Great spot to learn to snowboard. Didn't stay in accommodation
Nice place to go with children, easy slopes. Could be a bit boring skying for experienced riders.
Well run but very busy
Great place to learn to ski. Only 2.5 hours away from Melbourne
Entrance fee is too high and forced to have snow chains even there's no snow on the day or or snow on the road. Might be good for sky but not a great place for a tobogans.
Great addition of a rest room and warm rest area for public to have a meal free of charge.
Above the clouds....
Good place in winters.
My god so great

As the closest ski field to Melbourne, Mt. Baw Baw is best avoided on the weekends if you dont want to poleaxed by someone who doesn't know how to ski or thinks its appropriate to haul their 80kg adult carcass down a tobogan slope like a giggling idiot, ploughing into half a dozen kids.   Having to pay to use the tobogan conveyer just to escort a 5yo to the top of the run and safely send him down his own is a epic rip off.

If management does read this, perhaps actually given visitors an option of a footpath they can go up and down for free might be a option, as is designating a under 10s/family play area for toboganning/snow play to the kids don't get pummeled by adults might make the resort even more family friendly.  General lack of signage about, so had to walk about the place to find things that should be easy to find ( like lift passes)

Lastly, ( and this is very serious) the lack of designated, separate footpaths from the lower car parks to the entrance needs to addressed as forces visitors to share the road with vehicles in wet, slippery and low light conditions. This is an OH&S issue.
Nice place
Loved it bigg time.. xoxo
Great place for winter holiday
The toilets flushed well.

Check the weather before coming here. If there is no snow, you will be very depressed. Then... the road here is really bad, the mountain road has 18 bends. My personal suggestion is, if there is no room on the mountain, don't stay overnight, just go home after a day of fun.
Great little ski resort close to Melbourne. Need a decent fall for serious skiers but great for toboganning and kids on lighter falls.
nice views.
Had so much fun!!! Would definitely come again, if it wasn't for the prices. It's better to stay in one of the resorts at the top of the mountain and have fun for as long as your there for.

Was charged $35 for snow chain on a sunny  day, no falling snow, even no snow on roads. Was charged $10 for tobogganing on fake durty snow whilst it's free in Lake Mountain. Dissatisfied! Lake Mountain is far much better and reasonable.
$56 just to go up is a bit much..
Great place for families and kids

Great day trip, just over an hours drive from Traralgon. Car "parking" was 57$ but that was pretty much an entrance fee, they have chain hire + fitting for 30$ which I wish i knew before I rented my own. Food was decent, all meals were around 15$ with chips, rental gear was around 60$ for the day but goes half price from 1pm. Definitely more for beginners/ family but a great little day trip for my friend who had never seen the snow.

No space for tobogganing... We need to argue that where we can do it, officer was suggesting a place where there wasn't any snow and hard surface, which is very risky. Ultimately after big argument we able to some toboggans. Over all okay experience.

Kids loved it. Ski instructor Brett was awesome teaching my 9yr old, who was lucky enough to have a 1on1 session for 1.5hrs. The kids under 6yr group session of 3hrs, probably went for a bit to long as it upset my 6yr old, who admitted there was to much waiting and she felt really bored. Avoiding the peak school holiday period makes all the difference and arriving early from 8am for a prime parking spot is also key
Snowboarding for the first time, almost got a conclusion but was wearing a helmet 10/10 would go again!
Great coffee and a view if you can manage it
Loved it
good only 3 hour drive from epping melbourne north
Absolute amazing experiance. Loved Mt. Baw Baw, especially the huskies and really good customer service.
Nice place to enjoy
Very pleasant staff at cafe
Excellent!
Great place for a visit
A must first place to go to get everything u need to know
Alpine dingo x 2 in cage. Bit of info. View not as good as Mt Buffalo.
Great not far from Melbourne
Great place, easy to get to and closest snow resort to Melbourne.More for family than for experienced skiers
best place for person new in skiing..
Awesome Ski resort for beginners and intermediates. The food is also pretty good on the restaurants.
Really friendly staff, helps so much with understanding how to put snow chains on our car, never done it before. Thanks
Super
Really good
Quite expensive.
It's actually nice and quiet when I went on the off peak period which was mid to end August
We spent a nice afternoon in the ice. Who wants to know about expense - paid 25 AUD for tire chains and 56 AUD per car. A perfect place for hanging out in the ice, tobogan and skiing activities.
Best winter fun. You can go for tabboging and skiing and the snow view is epic

Was very disappointed with the hire shop at mount Baw Baw the kids pants were soaked after just an hour and a half, when I told the manager about it he said it's only supposed to keep you warm. Ridiculous, will never recommend anyone to hire their clothing.

Good place, make sure to hire a snow chain before you go there and don't expect to hire from there.

If you don't have a chain, they tell you they don't have chain which fits your tyre size. I'm not sure whether it's true or not, they told me and for  least 10-15 vehicles while I was waiting there.

Subject: Safety Concern at Perisher Ski Resort

Dear Perisher Ski Resort Team,

I'm writing this review in the hope that it prompts some changes to improve safety on the slopes. Currently, it appears that anyone -- including those who have never skied before -- can simply arrive at the resort, rent equipment from outside vendors, park, walk in, and head straight to the lifts without any skill check or guidance.

There seems to be no procedure or regulation in place to ensure that visitors have at least basic skiing or snowboarding skills before accessing the slopes. This lack of oversight increases the risk of injury -- not only to inexperienced individuals but also to others on the mountain.

For example, a young lady had a loose snowboard hit her spine while she was sitting and listening to her instructor. The owner of the board had no idea how to ride it or how to place it face down so it doesn't slide down the slope and hit someone.

I strongly suggest introducing a process to verify that all guests have at least basic ability before they're allowed on certain slopes. Even a quick assessment or dedicated beginner check-in area could go a long way toward preventing accidents and making the resort safer for everyone.

Overall, I had a great time :).

Thank you for considering this feedback.

Massive Terrain, But Expect the Crowds

Perisher is a truly massive resort and offers an incredible amount of terrain, making it a fantastic destination for all levels of skiers and snowboarders. The sheer scale and variety of runs are its greatest strengths; you could spend days here without skiing the same run twice. From the beginner-friendly slopes to the more challenging black diamond runs and well-maintained terrain parks, there's a huge amount to explore.

However, the size of Perisher also brings its biggest challenge: the crowds. On busy weekends and during peak season, the lift lines can get quite long, especially at popular chairlifts, which can eat into your ski time. While the lift network is extensive, some of the older lifts can also be a bit slow. The atmosphere is vibrant and lively, but it can sometimes feel more focused on volume than on providing a charming, boutique experience.

Overall, if you're looking for the largest amount of terrain in Australia and can plan your visit to avoid the peak crowds, Perisher is an excellent choice. It's a huge mountain with great potential, but a few operational improvements could easily push it to a full 5 stars.

I've been skiing at Perisher and Smiggins since 2000 and have skied overseas in Cardrona (NZ) multiple times. Perisher and Smiggins have made next to no updates in all this time. Car parking has always been grossly inadequate. There is insufficient seating and space capacity considering the volumes of patrons (people who have paid thousands to ski/board there) they allow entry too. The food is grossly overpriced and low quality and services understaffed by rude, unfriendly, unprofessionally dressed/presented, disengaged, obnoxious 20 somethings. Tables are not wiped clean between customers or rubbish disposed off... absolutely unacceptable given the past two years of Convid, in which this resort loved virtue signalling just how much they "care about health". Bathroom facilities are absolutely disgusting .. not cleaned and rubbish all over floors.

Lifts are not built for the average season conditions - particularly wind. Lifts are continually on wind hold, forcing people to cram onto a few available lifts and wait 45 minutes to an hour or more to get on a chair lift. We love parking at Smiggins, as you can park right by the entrance of the far right building near the j bars and use them to access to link t-bar and ski to Perisher.But NO.... the past 3 years in a row Perisher REFUSED to open the link t-bar, meaning you have to either park at Perisher and walk significant distances from the car park, or use the shuttle bus. Lifts to Blue Cow were closed while we were there this season and Perisher had the nerve to advise patrons to use the ski tube instead, but then operated it in a reduced schedule, claiming (the underground skitube train) was impacted by strong winds. It's an endless money grab by Perisher!!!

We heard the situation is based on one car out followed by one car in.  I can see many cars were leaving Perisher Valley Resort, but no car was allowed to go in. I was so frustrated with the situation as I have already bought the lift tickets for the whole family. We went to the restaurant near the checkpoint for lunch and resting. At around 2pm, suddenly it was allowed to go in. We were lucky to be in the first group to drive in. When we arrived at the Perisher Valley Ski Resort, it was so easy to find parking, inside the rest area where people eat and rest, it was less busy as well. I struggle to appreciate the reasoning of denying the access for a few hours. Totally unnecessary. In the past the ski resort was much busier, never denying people for access. I tried to email Perisher Ski Resort to check if it was possible to transfer the lift pass from day time to evening time, unfortunately no response. On Sunday, we deliberately got there early just in case of denied access due to the full capacity. Luckily I didn't see the police checkpoint. When arrived at Perisher Ski Resort, it was very difficult to find parking. It took me over 35 minutes. Overall I did enjoy the beautiful moments on the snow, but not a good experience in terms of denied access on Saturday.

Perisher Valley is absolutely magical - the snowfall was incredible and the kids had an amazing time playing in the snow. It's a winter wonderland and truly a beautiful spot for a snow holiday.

However, I would not recommend visiting during the peak school holiday season. The traffic was completely out of control. By 8:30 AM, the resort parking was full and thousands of cars were being turned back, with no prior updates or warnings. We saw the same chaos at Thredbo as well.

We ended up losing our bookings - and a lot of money - due to this poor management. There's a serious lack of infrastructure and communication to handle peak crowds. It's clear the area hasn't been upgraded to support the number of visitors it receives during holidays.

Extremely poor experience for beginners - Smiggin Holes Ski School should not advertise beginner lessons if they don't support first-timers.

I booked a beginner group lesson at Smiggin Holes (Perisher), which included a mandatory lift pass. I received no instruction, no help, and the instructor didn't take us to the lift. As a first-time skier, I was completely lost and left alone.

When I asked staff why we weren't taken to the lift, they told me it was because I didn't ask. That response is completely unacceptable -- how is a beginner supposed to know what to ask for?

I couldn't use the lift pass, didn't receive a lesson, and was denied a refund. I didn't even get a receipt, and all complaints were handled verbally with no accountability. Staff said they weren't responsible for the instructor -- shocking.

This felt like a scam. I paid a lot of money for nothing. If you're a beginner, do NOT go to Smiggin Holes Ski School. They are absolutely not prepared to support first-timers.

We visited Perisher last week and found it overwhelmingly busy. Lift pass queues were frustratingly long, and once on the slopes, the heavy traffic made it difficult to enjoy the snow. It often felt crowded rather than relaxed, which took away from the overall experience.

Another surprise was the lack of facilities -- there weren't many places to sit down, put on boots, or get sorted before hitting the slopes. Even something as simple as more benches or undercover areas would go a long way.

For family members who aren't skiing, it was hard to find a comfortable spot to sit, stay warm, and just enjoy the mountain atmosphere. A quiet area to read a book or take in the view would've made a real difference.

Perisher has a great location, but the crowding and lack of practical amenities made this visit less enjoyable than we'd hoped.

I would like to share a disappointing experience I had at Perisher Resort.

Yesterday, I purchased a morning lift ticket at around 11:00 AM from the ticket counter. The staff did not inform me that this ticket was only valid until 1:00 PM, and that it might be better to purchase an afternoon pass instead due to the time.

Later, I realized the limited validity of the morning ticket and returned to ask if I could change to an afternoon ticket. I was told this was not possible, and that I would have to pay an extra $34 for a full-day ticket.

After reading through the lift ticket terms and conditions on the official Perisher website (as shown in the attached image), I couldn't find any policy that explicitly prohibits changing the time slot for a same-day ticket -- especially when the ticket was purchased shortly before the morning session ended.

I believe this miscommunication cost me an extra $270 unnecessarily, and could have been avoided with a simple explanation or recommendation from the staff.

As someone who does not speak English fluently and was visiting Perisher for the first time alone, I feel that the staff should have made the situation clearer.

I hope Perisher Resort can improve the communication and ticketing process to help guests -- especially international visitors -- make more informed choices.

Thank you for your understanding.

We had a fantastic family trip to the Perisher valley mountain! The kids loved tobogganing down gentle slopes and building snowmen. There were easy trails perfect for beginner skiers, and we even had a short ski lesson together. The snow play area was safe and well managed, with lots of space to run around. We enjoyed hot chocolate in the warm cafe while watching the snow fall. The views were stunning, and everything was well organised for families. It was a great place to make winter memories, and we can't wait to come back next year for more snow fun! Of all, kids had a great time and are keen to do more skiing.

Beautiful location had plenty of snow. I wish there was an area with a big fireplace or something to warm up as it was so cold! The lodge area was not heated so there was little reprieve from the cold and limited food options.

I came to perisher to ski for the first time, but I found it was quite overpriced for lift tickets and  rentals. The lack of signs made it hard to find your way around, especially if you've never been there before. They had lots of options from first timers to very experienced skiers/boarders. The food places were way overpriced and pretty average tasting. Most restaurants didn't even accept cash. It was fun but not great value. Also, I don't recommend toboganning here as they don't have a conveyor belt to get back up the hill, so it was very tiring climbing back up.
Easy to get to on the bus. Lots of people and a real buzz. Don't take your car, the lot is full before 7am. Stay at Jindabyne if you're doing a cheap holiday. The resorts are $$$$$.

I read in one of the reviews "this place is called perisher because your money just perishes here!" lol.. So true! We visited Perisher Ski Resort this weekend (21/06/25) I booked Ski lessons for my 11 year old daughter and myself. I was annoyed to find out after forking out for the expensive lessons ($280 in total). They said you can't join a ski lesson unless you pay for ski lift. The whole point of taking a lesson is you can't use the ski lift because you are a beginner! I had to fork our another $280 to use a travelator they call magic carpet (not ski lift) because it was essential part of the lesson. Thankfully, they cordoned the kids area so to filter out the rush. But if you taking adult lessons, you would need to queue-up and wait 20 mins to get on the bloody "magic carpet". I told the lady in the office as well, their "policy" was a big time rip-off. When someone is already paying for the lessons, travelator use should be included in your ticket. I can understand, if people feel confident they can buy ski lift pass separately. But to join your beginner lesson you shouldn't try to rip-off as customers have already paid for the instructor time and use of the facility. Anyone reading this review, if you are a beginner, and want lessons. Go to Mt. Selwyn, which is where I would be heading next time.

The resort is huge with an abundance of runs. That's about all it has going for it. Ticket prices (not to mention food prices on the hill) are exorbitant. Service is terrible, with most staff clearly not too happy to be there. Parking is terrible with many walking more than a kilometre along the road to get to the lifts. When you get there, the lines are the worst you will find anywhere in the world, including further up the mountain. No gondolas, no heated or hooded chairs either. A minimal number of runs are groomed. Pick your timing well, as there is rarely sufficient snow. You'll find MUCH better value and conditions almost anywhere else in the world...

Good place for both easy riders and experts and the worst place in terms of resort operation. As I have experience for both Thredbo and Perisher, Thredbo will be the better place for first people who seek the first snow sports experience. Even if you have a good ski level, you may get injured due to the lift operator, and it can be seen easily that they do not take any safety measure when the rider fell off the lift. They focus on better flow, but not safety. The average price is cheaper than Thredbo, so it's only a good place if you are really willing to pay for injuries caused by non-professional staff. Safety and customer service need to be improved. All you need to know is that Vail Resort(Perisher) is the largest resort but not a No.1. Thredbo is Australia's best ski resort.

We recently embarked on a trip to Perisher to get some skiing/boarding into our legs (5 adults/5 young teens). Despite the fact that we did have lots of fun, pretty good snow & a great experience in general - bottom line is: What one gets for what one pays is not really balanced. The lift equipment is ancient (esp. charilifts without foot rests). Hospitality offerings on the mountain reminded me on the 80s. But especially ticket prices are mind blowing. 2 to 4 times what one would pay in modern proper ski ressorts overseas. 250+ dollars for a day pass is just too much.

My family and I ski here every year and absolutely love this place. This season, I decided to purchase 5 advanced ski lessons just to tidy up my form and to improve my carving. I booked for the lessons to be at the same time every day and basically had the same people in the class all the way through. However, every day we had a different instructor who asked us what we wanted to focus on, rather than assessing what we need to do to improve. We had to relearn things we'd already gone over and teachers taught vastly different. This made it difficult to improve each day because we'd be focusing on something a little bit different rather than building upon knowledge from the day before. On the Friday they didn't even offer an advanced class and I was stranded in a mixed ability group which didn't necessarily cater to the more advanced skiers.
Most instructors were good, however I had three instructors who wouldn't actually watch anyone ski enough to offer really tailored or personal advice.

Overall, I would still recommend lessons if anyone feels out of control, or even if they want to feel better about their skiing. Basically, everyone will get something out of it. However, it could be far more effective if one instructor was put on a specific level for the whole week.
Banging good ski location with plenty of runs and good vibes. Friendly staff too!

This is terrible. Do not go here! Insane price of almost 300$ a day and they have the worst possible chair lifts: slow and without a bar for ski rest. Also a lot of T-bars, which is insane for this price.

"I had an incredible time snowboarding at Perisher Mountain! The variety of runs catered to all skill levels, from gentle slopes for beginners to challenging terrain for more advanced riders. The snow conditions were excellent, with fresh powder that made for a thrilling experience.

The lift system was efficient, minimizing wait times and allowing us to maximize our time on the slopes. I also appreciated the friendly staff and well-maintained facilities, including cozy lodges for warming up and grabbing a bite to eat.

The scenery was breathtaking, with stunning views of the surrounding mountains. Overall, Perisher is a fantastic destination for snowboarding, and I can't wait to return for more adventures!"

We had the pleasure of having Ben (Benoit Vidotto) as our private full day instructor on 03/08/2024.

We couldn't be more grateful for his exceptional patience and dedication. Despite our group of six having varying levels of experience, Ben ensured that each one of us received personalized attention and instruction. His ability to teach us with such care and perseverance, especially while navigating the challenging slopes, was truly remarkable. Ben's professionalism and expertise have made our skiing experience unforgettable. We wholeheartedly believe he is an outstanding instructor.

They call this place Perisher because your money just perishes. Bring lots of money with you because you will pay through your teeth for everything. Arranged lessons for my beginner level children and they claim that it is mandatory to pay for lift tickets even though they don't use the chair lifts. I disputed this charge and basically their response was "too bad"!! The cost for two hour lessons with non use of the chair lift was $600. What a scam!! Other scams prices was the price of a hot chocolate $10, a small muffin $12, small hot chips $10.

The Perisher provided trainer for the lessons was called Paddy and he was extremely poor in teaching my kids. He lacked patience and wasn't very clear in explaining the techniques. I could see as I was watching the entire time that other members from the group were getting extremely upset at the trainer.

To conclude I won't be visiting the area ever again as it's just a money making scheme and the snow is gradually getting lesser and lesser each year. The snow report prior to heading to Perisher was "expected snow fall over night with cloud and gusty winds" when we arrived on the day it was clear with no wind and no snow falls which is another lie/scam the Perisher website cons you to visit.

Perisher fix your parking for people that buy day passes and yearly passes this is getting beyond a joke they closed the road because your car park is too full yet you still accept the money from tickets sort this out now . it's been going on to long over selling tickets.

Perisher Valley offers a great skiing experience for families and serious snow enthusiasts alike. The slopes cater well to all skill levels, with excellent ski school programs for beginners and challenging runs for advanced skiers and snowboarders. The convenience of onsite snowsport hire makes gearing up easy, and the cafeteria provides decent food options at fair prices. However, be prepared for potentially long queues during peak times, and keep an eye on snow conditions as they can be variable. Despite these minor drawbacks, Perisher Valley remains a top choice for winter sports in Australia, promising unforgettable moments on the slopes.

I had a terrible experience with this resort. I purchased a half-day pass for myself and my partner, but we only got to use it for two hours due to tremendous traffic and police blocking the road. It is ridiculous that I purchased the pass, bought a bus ticket, and left for the resort two hours before my booking start time for what should have been a 30-minute drive using public transport, which should be punctual. Yet, we ended up using only two hours of our expensive pass.
When I reached out to customer service, they were incredibly rude and dismissive, completely ignoring me and ruining my time there. I spent a lot of money getting there and renting gear, but even with all of that, when I saw the crowd and the long lift line with only two hours left, I begged them to transfer my pass to another day. They refused, saying that since I still had two hours left, they couldn't do anything. I am extremely disappointed and would never expect such awful customer service from Perisher. They easily oversell the passes but behave like scammers when it comes to accommodating their users and customers.

Family of 5. More expensive lift tickets then thredbo. Hugely more expensive for kids lessons which are also shorter duration. Kids have a small lunch whereas thredbo they can eat until they are full. More wind holds than thredbo, wait lines commonly 30 min on holidays. Long drive in - 45 from jindy or more if snowing or chains needed. The tube is faster but so expensive we just couldn't justify it.

Honestly if you're a family I would go to Thredbo or New Zealand. Even if the snow isnt as good we end up skiing more because lines are shorter!

Negligent staff, old lifts, too expensive.

Perisher is a lovely resort, especially from the perspective of someone who has skied extensively in the European Alps. However, I am concerned about the safety of younger skiers and snowboarders. The old chairlifts are particularly problematic as they move too fast and lack sufficient personnel to assist, especially at the top.

Recently, my child got stuck while disembarking, causing him to panic and jump from a height of three meters. The lift attendant did not stop or slow down the lift, nor did they assist us promptly. Thankfully, my son wasn't injured even though he had a second blackout, but the incident was frightening.

I urge other parents to closely watch and help their children disembark from the old chairlifts, as there is a noticeable lack of safety measures and staff support!!!
Rip off lift ticket prices
