purchased skiing lesson and epic pass, was advised by them to cancel both due to covid on june, but it takes them one week to response the first email, and never got back to me regarding refund after first email, even I waited for nearly 2 months, and fair trading cannot even get contacted with them too, is this resort bankrupted or what? where is  the customer service team????

what i love the most is it's an easy to navigate resort  well laid out lifts so you can travel long distances easily and there is always a good spot even when the weather is off. and you can get indoors if needed.

perisher is a very wide mountain resort  lots of runs varying skill levels and well sign posted and it's super safe. the snow is never that deep which is good and bad.

bad if it's not been snowing much it's icy and hurts to fall (get lessons)

good you can find your way around and you won't get into a situation where you fall upside down or can't get up because the snow is so deep.

food is dear at the snow as it has to come a lot further up with difficult access so it's all at a premium and that's fair they have to make 4x profit to make it worth their while for the few months they are open.  don't skimp on food and drinks because of cost, your doing hard physical exercise you need to sleep and eat well to have any fun and go easy or don't even drink alcohol.

my favourite place to eat is the Japanese noodles place!

perisher has good shops to up grade any equipment you have and i found their prices reasonable , surprisingly. which was great when goggles got foggy and stocks were fallen on. and extra clothing at fair prices to keep the girls rugged up warm.

when i used to hire equipment i used rhythm in cooma they have a huge shop and always have good hire equipment that rotates each year it's not old and worn out. plus you can buy your own gloves googles and other warm things to keep everyone purring and happy.

My season pass I paid $1000 for didn't work, so we had to ski down to the bottom and spend an hour sorting it. Further, there was no notification that my existing card would be loaded with my new season pass. Of course you have to pay $5 for a plastic card. In whistler, they're free.

I was advised from hospital my leg was going to be a 3-6month recovery time, but unfortunately that was not the case. I requested a refund before the season even started and  perisher requested me waste another $50 on getting a medical certificate written up only to still reject my request. As a previous staff member of the mountain i am very disappointed and at this point i'm not sure if i ever want to return to this money hungry businesses mountain

The guest service is just arbitrarily poor. We had lessons booked and their terms of service say you can't move the lessons within 48 hours (unless it suits them). But there is clearly plenty of availability for the lessons on the day we booked and the day we asked to move (because of predicted poor weather, not change of mind) and rather than just press a couple of buttons and move the date, they spend the same amount of time sending an email back saying sorry, you've asked something that couldn't even be achieved by a Royal Commission. Overall this is the second time we've been this year and the facilities are poor and dated, their guest services are useless and their policies are just unnecessarily convoluted and negative. The experience has made it likely that I will never return to a ski field in Australia and just go to (unbelievably) cheaper and better run ski fields in other countries. Well done team.

Firstly, the parking situation is appalling. The car park was full early on so we were asked to park on the side street at the car park entrance. We then carried our 3 year olds and their snow gears all the way to ski school, it is very far. We were late of course and they were banned from joining the class and reasons given were inconsiderate, lies and motivated to just take your money for the day and move on. Coordinating lady in red were rude, spoke down to us and the next day terrorised us and our kids. They've labelled the area for first timers but really aren't able to cater first timers needs and have scarred our children from what could be a positive ski experience. Our kids were asked to leave because the instructors were not able to handle too many struggling kids. A whole lot of other kids were crying but they were not asked to leave because their parents aren't there. The facilities are so dated and the exorbitant food aren't up to standards at all. Extremely disappointing and will not return. We also collectively found staffs were racist, we were spoken to and treated differently. In this day and age in a tourist destination, it is very sad and disappointing to see. In summary it was a complete rip off experience for us.

We did not stay at the resort overnight, instead visited as day skiers. The resort was crowded during school holidays, as expected for all Australian ski resorts, but the lack of value for money was the major issue.

One aspect that particularly disappointed us was the locker rental. We rented a locker onsite and initially planned to use it for three days. However, upon receiving a recommendation from our coach, we opted to practice at Smiggin Holes due to shorter queues and more beginner-friendly tracks. When I approached the resort officers to request a refund for the remaining days, they directed me to fill out an enquiry form online. After patiently waiting for three days, I finally received a response. To my dismay, they informed me that the lockers were operated by a contractor, and as a result, no refund could be issued. This inconsistency and lack of responsibility on the part of the resort management were truly frustrating.

Overall, the Perisher resort failed to meet our expectations and left us feeling dissatisfied. The high prices, overcrowding, and lack of accountability regarding the locker rental all contributed to my decision to give it a 2-star rating. I would caution others to consider these factors before choosing to visit this resort.

The private lesson instructor Laura ended private class earlier than the time should be. The private lesson should be end at 4 but Laura ended at 3.43 pm one the first day and 3.40 pm on the second day. Even after the parent communicated with her to end class at 4 pm or at least between 3.45pm - 4 pm she insisted to end the class at 3.40pm. One day of the whole day private lesson cost 1277 AUD and the duration of the class should be from 9am-4pm. Make complainant to the instructor's supervisor, a female supervisor always said she would contact the parent but never did. A male supervisor said he would call back but till we leave the resort he hasn't talked to us about how to solve it.

We went late June for one day at Perisher, and were very fortunate enough to have vivid fresh snow. We parked at Bullocks Flat, took the Skitube and got off at Perisher Valley, hurried over to Perisher Centre to get rental snow jacket and pants, and the skiing boots, helmet and skis. Goggles and neck scarfs are byo or buy in venue and are recommended on very snowy days. Bags and shoes placed in small-ish rental lockers that were roughly the size of a microwave each. We took the 9am beginners lesson and the instructors are very friendly. All this was easily booked and paid online via the perisher website where you'll get a QR code to scan at the ticket machines there and print out a Mountain access card for each person. Like some others have said, Perisher Valley isn't the most beginner friendly, even their Front Valley slope is steep in some areas and need decent steering skills to minimise falling over. Thredbo has a better kid and beginner friendly area close to ground. The queues to the chairlifts are iconically long during the winter peak + school holidays period but they do take you quite high up the mountain so it's worth the thrill gliding down.
Snow was awesome we had a great time skiing

Perisher charges a premium for its name and yet is unable to manage their lifts operation effectively to service the skiers. I was there from Thursday last week till Saturday and most lifts were closed. The funny thing was that the triple lift in sniffing a was open and not the tBar, wind on Saturday was strong but wasn't too bad and surely the tBar could be operated. I heard that they were understaffed which makes sense. Whilst they knew is going to be windy they still advertise that they are going to open the lifts but in reality only 2 lifts were open in perisher.

Dated facilities and crowded! Its time to upgrade and update your facilities. You are charging mega bucks but your services and basic facilities are nowhere near what we are paying. Parents have nowhere to go when others are skiing away! Food prices are exorbitant! $9 for a bottle of drink? $23.50 for a kebab? Seriously??? Locker facilities have been updated recently and so has the prices! A small locker will set you back $22 per night? Its now cheaper to go skiing overseas like Queenstown and Japan. You will never be able to boost the local tourism with these. Reflection required!

Loved this mountain till I spoke 2 minutes with head of pathways Katie Kreczman. She has absolutely no customer service skills and was the most rude individual I have ever encountered in 45 years of skiing and 25 years skiing with vail resorts around the world. Husband worked for them for years and he couldn't believe the way Katie spoke and reacted to a basic query of why kids weren't training on the race flags set up and why kids who are 6 not the correct  the age of the program less than 100 cm tall and can't ski a black run or can't buckle their boots in the program taking up all the coaches time. If you can't  handle a question and falsely advertise a program you shouldn't be working for vail resorts. Hotham and Thredbo are now my favorites in Australia. Go here almost every year and it is always great! Has a great variety of runs of varying length and difficulty so there is an option for everyone. Some of my personal favourite runs include; kamikaze (a harder run for older and more experienced skiers) and rollercoaster in Blue Cow, Wood Run (great for kids and new skiers) and Blanchy's in Smiggins Holes, Powder Ridge (probably the easiest black thats ever open) and Goat's Gully in Front Valley Towers run and GS Bowl (should be a black) in Mount Perisher, and Easy Rider (very long but easy) and Mother in Law in Guthega.

Perisher also has great cafes and other restaurants/food places throughout for a great break from skiing with excellent food and drinks, my personal favourite and recommendation is the Pretty Valley Kiosk due to its incredible hot chocolates. If you are in Front Valley during lunch I would also recommend taking a trip to the Perisher Centre as it has a series of restaurants, cafes and shops to buy ski gear if yours breaks.

Even though Perisher Resort is huge, if you are even just an intermediate skier you can pretty easily make it the whole way around the resort and back if you know the way or just follow the signs as they are very helpful.

And i pay for that very thing. If it happens next this year you can expect to get the bills.

No way to contact them aside from email; and as mentioned, good luck getting a response. Appalling CS.'

snow was surprisingly great for September and was very well kept. All of the chair and T bar were up and running and the queues were short. Some of the runs were a bit icy but not too bad and could be skied right over. I recommend you leave as early as possible to get a parking spot because it gets insanely packed very quickly. It would've been five stars if it hadn't been for the nasty comments from Josh about our "mentally slow" fellow learners. on the first day, we had Joe and he was amazing and very encouraging and compassionate. He walked us through the process and understood that snowboarding is challenging. to our surprise, on the second day we had Josh and and he was rude and made snarky comments about our performance. We had never been snowboarding before and were new to the sport and we deserved more respect then what we were given.
The station is super big. The trails are varied and the landscape is magnificent. I usually ski in Japan and Queenstown in NZ, and this is much better than Queenstown without hesitation.

Do not honour season pass refunds. A consistent issue, well known by the ACCC and fair trading. They'll take your money in a heart beat, but you'll never hear from them when lodging a refund request (supported by the correct paperwork as dictated by their own T&Cs). No way to contact them aside from email; and as mentioned, good luck getting a response. Appalling CS.

We had a family emergency and we are not able to ride the following day and as we pre purchased our tickets, we were declined our refund by the manager, we did email the day before (24 hours) before the slopes opened the next day.
In the terms in conditions it does not state that cancellations must be made at 12am today for our tickets for tomorrow. We have snow boarded around the world and have never experienced this kind of poor service and to think this is in our own country is very upsetting, will not be returning. Absolutely wonderful experience as a beginner at Perisher! We booked a beginners class and it was 10/10 worth it. We had 2 wonderful instructors, Andy Aitken and Daisy to the 6 of us and they were absolutely so professional and friendly with their teaching approach. They are clearly experts in their field as I was able to spend the remainder of the days at the snow zipping around thanks to them! All the other staff we encountered on the mountain were also so friendly too. 10/10 will visit again and highly recommend getting lessons!

Everything that's wrong with the Australian tourism industry in one place. The place itself is beautiful but ruined by greedy, low service operators.There's no attempt to even pretend anymore that they're not seeking rent by price gouging for access to a priceless national resource.

For example:
- Extremely high prices by global standards.
- All infrastructure and equipment is old and of the cheapest possible quality.
- Simple things like ski racks on the Ski Tube or shelter near the car park are missing.
- Basic services like looking after your shoes after hiring skis and boots not available. "We don't do that". I had to carry my shoes in my backpack or walk a long way back to my car.
- Won't store ski hire overnight. "You have to take them with you mate."
- Don't build capacity to match customer numbers. It's normal to find nowhere to sit at lunchtime.
- Force you to walk all over the place in ski boots. Ski Tube is a couple of hundred metres from the lifts and up and down stairs. Better to save money on a bit of extra track and make your customers walk than take them where they're actually trying to go.
- Basic things like signs are missing. Had to walk around asking people in shops to find the kids ski school.
- Accommodation prices that would get you a 5 star resort elsewhere will get you the equivalent of a dirty hostel here.

Australia needs to wake up that it's not 1980 anymore and visitors expect reasonable prices and good service.

Really great place to visit during winter season and stay for a few days. Lots of activities to do like skiing and snowboarding for beginners to intermediate. Theres a place for kids and children to enjoy toboggan and play snowman. Make sure to come early coz parking gets full. Few food stores you can order inside the centre aswell and some souvenirs.

Huge ski resort with many and various runs. There is a place for most skiers here and many social media advice pages so I dont need to add to it here except for the following.
A) this place is popular and busy, don't come here to relax.
B) prices are not outrageous but a day of takeaway food costs a lot.
C) skiing early is often icy. The best snow is later in the day.
D) it is very easy to loose friends and family here, bring phones.

I love Perisher, but, if I am picky, I wound make the following suggestions: a) a T-bar from Blue Cow Terminal to enable return to Perisher when the lifts are closed due to wind to avoid having to queue for the Skitube and b) some rope-pulls across Perisher Creek to assist getting between Perisher and Smiggins...

Although the winter prices are super heavy possibly even a Lil criminal considering the staff are the only  update  this place has had in the last 15-20 yrs I've been visiting .. its still one of my favourite places to ride & visit on this planet .. gumtrees beer & snow ! My type of happy place !

Came for a feed with friends.  Food wasn't bad but not many food options either.  It was pretty pricy,  and most items averaged at $25+ (not including drinks) but apparently a standard price for perisher.

I ordered the beef lasagna with chips.  You get to choose chips or mash and add vegetables too.
The chips were a good serving size and really nice and crispy.  You could fill up on chicken salt and condiments to your liking on the self serve desk.

The beef lasagna was not bad.  It was a bit mushy in the centre,  however it was a good size and they had a good chunk of cheese on top of the lasagna; just the way I like it.

I ate around 1:30pm and the line was still pretty long,  however not a long wait as they do serve you pretty quickly.  Staff were nice and friendly too.
Good one.
Amazingly beautiful place.

Mixed feelings about Perisher. It has some great slopes and the sheer size of the ski fields is enormous. The staff are super friendly and it seems like a big family of like minded people.

The facilities feel like they are struggling to keep pace with the millions of dollars spent up on the mountain every year. The inflexible way access to the mountain and the chair lifts operates make it hard to justify forking out a small fortune when it feels like a gamble on the weather. Sometimes you win and get consecutive days of great weather but sometimes you don't and just bleed money for nothing in return.

It would be convenient to blame Covid but in reality these things were problems before Covid and nothing has really changed.

A few things that should be on the radar:
- Old and tired locker space needs improving and modernising. Make better use of the space and update the low security padlock/keys to something more 21st Century.
- Some flexibility in lift access passes  such as 3 or 4 days in a week, rather than  enforced consecutive days. Allows you to have a rest day if you like, or take a day off when the weather is poor.
- Same as the previous point with the NSW National Parks access.
- Car parking at Perisher could be vastly improved. The car park is woefully inadequate on busy days. Expanded facilities at Smiggins wouldn't hurt either.

Not expecting miracles. Snow sports will continue to be an expensive option in Australia. I am fortunate to be able to enjoy it.
Lines are long runs short lift tickets are expensive. But it is Australia so what do you expect

Wonderful Resort. Contains runs available for multiple types of riders. Blue cow is Great if you want a slightly quieter slope, which generally has better "snow quality" and more "powder". The learning slope there is great, and Lessons happen there too, which I recommend more then Front Valley. Speaking about that, Front Valley is Perisher's main advertised ski learning area, which is not a great area to start off at. The slope is always busy, and too steep to learn on. Great places here to ski with your family (Smiggins Holes, Happy Valley). Just if you're planning on driving up to Perisher anytime after 8am on the weekend, forget it. Just take the skitube, much easier but it can be busy.

The ski school booking and management system is very rigid an inflexible. There is no system for easily confirming what classes have been booked and when your upcoming classes are scheduled. It is difficult to make any adjustments or changes. It also not possible to make a future booking with a specific instructor. The only option is to make a request online, however there is no confirmation or guarantee of who you will get, and no refund if your preferred instructor is not available. Improvements could be made in this area. Other than that we enjoy the resort.

Biggest rip off ever. You are actually driving patrons offshore with your price gouging.It's cheaper to ski overseas then locally. They were rolling, tobaggoing, skiing cable carrying, and generally busy making snowmen each doing their own fun thing.The journey by road was exhilarating and loved every minute of my time.

Today the family had a group lesson at Perisher.  We had mixed abilities on the snow as well as a large gap in ages.  I was a tad concerned how it would go.  Do yourself a favour if you get lessons and seek out Dory.  Young energetic bloke, entertaining as well as a great teacher. Without sounding condescending, a very impressive young man.

What more is there to say about Australia's biggest ski resort? It has something for everyone. The staff are super friendly and it's always refreshing to have a laugh with the lifties on a cold snowy day. The terrain varies so greatly that there are trails for all levels. One of the special things about Perisher is that you can access most parts of the mountain with an access trail. A big favourite is the traverse from Mt Perisher right over to Guthega.

Awesome place to take the family, great snow but very pricey, make sure you plan accommodation months in advance, as places book out fast, overall, Perisher is a wonderful mountain, has terrain for all abilities, and the staff on the mountain are amazing, super friendly and will have all the answers to your questions, Perisher is definitely a must do for any snow lover.

Service desk useless both times, couldn't fix the problem. Cost me 30minutes each time I had to go and line up to fix the problem with his lesson.  Time is money on the mountain.

This doesn't even take into account the wasted 30minutes at the start of ski school because they have no idea how to organise a bunch of kids eager for ski school. Go check out how other resorts do it Perisher and implement some positive changes. The most disorganised mountain resort I've been to. Perisher Ski Resort is one of the finest Skiing facilities in Australia. There are ample snow gear hiring options within and around it. There is hot food served within Perisher Ski Resort for a nominal price. Toilet facilities are also available which are frequently maintained and are relatively clean. We were traveling with three kids which included a one year old however the trip went smoothly. Don't forget to arrive early to get a parking spot bearby the resort otherwise, you have to catch a free bus to get there.

Premium price of $200 a day at the start of the season and there's brown patches all over the piste, half the lifts aren't open. They claimed the whole mountain was open early but they don't even have all the lifts running. Not even some magic carpets, tbars or lifts operating at the bottom. They seem to open more on the wknd but that's just so packed they only allow a certain amount of people in and aren't even allowing people in that have paid for national park ticket, accom and ski passes. Really badly managed!

Missing for the 5*: decent restaurants and food, a alpine village (currently has none), more events, concerts and shows.

As reference please follow Whistler

My favourite snow finding place. Great for non skies families. Kids friendly toboggan area which is not available in Thredbo. Ample parking, plenty rest rooms. Kudos to all perisher workers to make it accessible to us

Perisher ski fields are fantastic and we have had so many enjoyable times here however, ordering tickets online is very hard and if you ever get sick and need a refund or credit it is IMPOSSIBLE to get in contact with them. You usually wait at least 20 days for each email reply and the reply is usually unfriendly and not helpful. Don't try calling them, it is impossible to get through. It is such a shame that such a nice place has such a poor customer service attitude.

I went here in winter as a novice. The weather was cold and rainy. The lesson I'd paid for was too hard for me, I'm a reasonably fit 68 year old. We had very little practice at stopping, it was very slippery, we had to walk up slope sideways over and over which was very tiring. I gave up. I still had a nice time taking photos, riding the ski tube,  having expensive coffee. The scenery is beautiful. They won't let you ride the ski lift up and down,  so I couldn't even do that.

Always a great experience. Staff do their best. But I completely overwhelmed at peak times. Lessons are at ground level though they make you buy lift tickets. Lift tickets always a rip off. Take caution with everything you do. Especially the T bar lift which people tend to fly off with young children and get stuck halfway up the mountain. It's all part of the thrilling experience but take caution. I think that in future the safety will be improved.
Nice ski resort with a lot snow equipments and cafes.

The shear fact that it has 4 very different resort areas that are all Li ked by lifts (or ski tube) makes this the best Australian resort for choice of runs and terrain. It always seems to have more snow coverage than it's competitors. Plenty of 'on mountain' areas to eat to escape the larger village food court areas. Good discounts also if you get a season pass.

Be sure to get your national Park pass as rangers check car number plates every day.

Also be aware the car park fills very quickly on weekends. Ski tube from bullocks flat is always a sure thing to beat the car park issue and also saves fitting chains on snowy days.

Perisher is an amazing experience! And definitely worth the drive! Plenty of activities for everyone!

You have to choose exact consecutive days of purchasing a multi-day pass and no matter what the weather is it's when you have to ski! It's going to be raining next three days and we'll have to stick it up and ski in the rain or just loose our passes.
Not good enough! Resorts in New Zealand give you and two weeks your lift tickets, no questions asked. I'll go there instead.

We left Sydney 9am today just to ensure we can make it to the night ski session. Arrived Jindabyne at 4:30pm and quickly had dinner. But when arrived V8 nothing was running. Lifts have closed and snow was not groomed. I instantly realised the night ski session must've been ended. We were extremely disappointed. The night ski was still running last Saturday and there is no notification or information on the website or dashboard warning us  the night ski has ended. If we knew it, we could've left sydney a lot later and had a relax trip down here. Our plan would've changed completely. The night ski has been opening every saturday for the entire season. It is 29th September today, I don't understand that if you have your day session open why couldn't keep the night session or at least highlight to your customer the dates when night sessions are available. There is no information easily spotted on the dashboard or website saying the night session has ended. Terrible experience :(

I contacted customer services via the online form on the 13th June 2021.  I've  sent 2 follow up emails and messaged the team on facebook. I've  have had no reply.

The reason for contacting customer services was regarding the 9.45 Ski tube from Bullocks Flat to Perisher on Saturday 12th June.

The tube ride was a terrifying experience that was handled poorly by Perisher Ski Resort.  There was no communication from the conductor as to what was going on.  No PA system for them to communicate with us.  Children were crying and terrified.  People were confused and panicked about what was going on and what they should be doing. Smoke was filling the train and we were told the train was on fire.  It brings to the fore the questionable safety measures and emergency evacuation plans in place for the train service.

After an emergency exit we had to walk the remaining way on the train tracks with ski gear and small, crying children.

In addition, earlier that day I had to line up for 40 minutes at Bullocks Flat despite having booked everything online the prior day because the required email and QR code was not sent.

The "mountain money" offered to us late in the day is grossly inadequate, is not useful to us and in no way compensates for the experience of that morning.  It took another hour to calm down my family.  We lost an expensive half day of skiing due to the experience of the Perisher Skitube

Please respond to my emails.
Happiest place on earth!
Always a great trip. Only wish it was easier to call the office desk
Great place to visit with plenty of areas to be away from the masses, walking up hills with 2 foot of snow is a great way to find out how unfit you are.
Very white.

Perisher's culture is toxic. Management has a bunch of disgusting strategies pushed to staff to charge more and more and won't hesitate to lie when they are caught out. They utilise their lack of competition to strong arm people and when you complain, they tell you to shut up or go somewhere else knowing full well you have driven a very long way and have limited to no options. Appalling company with no ethics or morales. Hope covid sends this company bankrupt and another operator with some human decency will come in and take over.

good for first timer ski/board play and kids .  lot of other playing area without interupting ski/board area . safe toboggan area (flat surface)

Probably the biggest ski resort with some beautiful slopes between snow gums, if you want to ski in Australia in the snowy mountains!
That's why I give it any stars at all.
The reason why the the managing company should rethink their business model:
Their prices are a complete rip off: $199/1day ski pass and only half of the lifts open is not ok.
But worse than that: in this price the public transport with the ski tube or shuttle bus is not included, so most people prefer to drive their own cars up which is absolutely counterproductive for our environment.
Not any discounts at their ticket terminals even in the peak Covid season, no half day passes or 4 out of 5-passes etc.
Pricing policy is a complete failure and no, they don't have to make their money in 3 months...other resorts worlwide are in a similar situation and they manage to offer deals in other seasons for hikers, bikers and many more potential customers.
Guess, they have to re-think their business model, anyway they won't have my money again.
Skiing in NZ or in a 5-star Switzerland skiresort is cheaper. What a pitty!

I have been trying to get a refund on a epic seasons pass from Perisher costing $998 due to the lockdown but despite there being clear terms on their website for "epic coverage" that a covid lockdown is a qualifying event for a refund - Perisher arent replying to my emails and have closed down their telephone service. Non responsive.

I buggered my knee day 1 of 5. Perisher Ski Resort were super friendly and helpful in response. They guided me to the medical centre. Then offered us a full refund, as a credit to be used between now, and the end of next snow season. We were super happy with this result. It was quick, easy and friendly. We will definitely be back next year. But will play a little safer next time!  In the meantime, we got to enjoy camping at the snow.  Cheers Perisher!

It's been one month since the request, we emailed 4 times to follow up as I don't hear any response nor updates but the auto email reply. Called them but never answered. Good range of grades of skiing and excellent instructors. Run and lift signage is poor, making getting around and meeting people more difficult than it need be. Extremely expensive for a day in the snow. Don't mind paying the national park entry, but $190 for a day pass for adult skiing is ridiculous, add to that the exorbitant prices at the on site shops, poor quality of the facilities, and the fact that in general the staff aren't exactly friendly, I'd rather spend my money overseas and ski NZ for a whole lot less.
A week at perisher for a family of 4 would be $3200 just in lift passes, at least, then add on at least the same again for food and accommodation and you've got one expensive off-snow holiday. Staying on snow you'd double that.
The off snow ski hire places are quite reasonably priced, but on snow, you could buy for the price of a hire. 80 a day for a pair of ski pants at the resort?
The resort itself offers sort of reasonable skiing, but really, it's only just better than nothing.
NZ, the US and Canada, even Europe offer far better skiing, for a whole lot less money and much better resorts and runs. Sure there's a cost to get there, but if you are after a couple of weeks of great skiing,  don't go here.

Perisher is the best ski resort in Australia. It is the largest ski resort (was once three ski resorts, but then they all combined to create Perisher). There is ample amounts of lifts, T-bars everywhere to keep you going all day. A wide variety of greens, blue and black runs to suit everyone. Allow time to get up the skitube from the bottom, as it takes approximately 30 minutes. Lots of restaurants scattered around the resort as well! This experience so far has been absolutely woeful and of hundreds of fans on social media I have been able to find only three who have secured their reservation.

The lift tickets are VERY pricey (comparable to Vail or Aspen, Colorado) so much so one would think the resort would have modern equipment and chalets.. The chairlifts are from many decades ago (plastic teal slats with no padding or footbars) and are so uncomfortable and slow it was unbelievable. There are two high speed chairs lifts and more T bar lifts than I have ever seen. The chalets remind me of the first chalets I visited from the 80s in the hills of small towns. The entire experience was a blast from the past.  I suppose when you are one of the only resorts in the country to ski there isn't a priority to update/improve the infrastructure.

EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTED IN MANAGEMENT AT PERISHER!!!!! I Have bought a seasons pass for 3 years in a row now. My wife was pregnant and we found out at 24 weeks that she had preeclampsia which then developed to HELLP syndrome. This in short started to shut down her body as her liver was failing. The doctors had to deliver our baby boy at 26weeks in order to save her and his life and he is currently in the Neonatal intensive care unit and will be for sometime. I contacted PERISHER and told them situation and said I can get a letter from the hospital regarding this. I Asked them if I could extend my seasons pass to next year as i will be by his side in hospital everyday and will not be able to go down at all. THEY SAID NO. I ASKED FOR A CREDIT NOT A REFUND! VERY DISAPPOINTED!!

Perisher is the largest and most popular ski resort in the Southern Hemisphere and Australia. It encompasses four mountain peaks: Perisher, Smiggin, Blue Cow, and Guthega. There are trails suitable for beginners, intermediate, and advanced skiers. We recommend Guthega for its beautiful scenery and Alpine Eyre for its T-bar-style burger joint. There are night skiing and fireworks every Tuesday and Saturday. The resort uses contactless cards for convenience, and you can also check your ski lift history online or download an app. The downside is that the trails are relatively short and the ski passes are expensive, so avoid visiting during long Australian holidays.

Perisher (known as Perisher Blue until 2009) is the largest ski resort in the Southern Hemisphere.[1] Located in the Australian Snowy Mountains, the resort is an amalgamation of four villages (Perisher Valley, Smiggin Holes, Guthega, and Blue Cow) and their associated ski fields, covering approximately 12 square kilometres (5 sq mi), with the base elevation at 1,720 metres (5,640 ft) AHD, and the summit elevation of 2,054 metres (6,739 ft) at the top of Mount Perisher. 4.4 square kilometres (1.7 sq mi) of this area is covered by 240 snow guns, which are used to artificially supplement the natural snowfall.

Unfortunately Perisher seems to be way too focused on profits. They do not re-invest into making the resort better. Certain chairlifts are very old, slow and do not carry many people. These need replacing with newer, faster ones to get people where they need to go. Additionally, there are way too many T-bars which makes much of the resort inaccessible for beginners and snowboarders.

Retail and food outlets are very pricey. The best deal on the mountain was the $2 hot chocolate up at mid- station each morning til 10am. First tracks and night skiing are great and its fantastic that these are free with your Epic Australia pass.

Skitube is a convenient way to get up to Perisher each day, however, this is also quite expensive even if you add it onto your season pass. We were also disappointed that the skitube stopped running during October even though the ski lifts were still open. This made it very difficult to access the resort.

Overall, Perisher needs to invest in improving facilities, replacing old/ slow chairlifts and improve access to areas which are currently T-bar only.

The only challenge is Thredbo is lower in altitude and can become soft at the lower levels on sunny days. What I discovered by accident is Jindabyne is beautiful has a larger choice of restaurants compared to Thredbo ( plus has pool and cinema etc). It takes 10 min to drive to the ski tube from Jindabyne which takes you straight to Perisher ski resort, best of both worlds higher mountain and great village atmosphere at the end of the day.

Perisher is a great resort with plenty of options on offer.

As the season progresses with more snow the more parks and features become available. I'd like to see a mini pipe again and a quarter pipe setup next season pls. The mini pipe is a great way to learn and get used to dropping in etc. The mid station location was perfect where it was a few years back. Quarter pipe could go in either park near front valley.

Parking is what it is, get there early and you won't have issues in busy times.

What is the area like to play in? Fantastic! So many options and if you wish you will never ski or board the same run in the one day. I usually start over at Eyre and work my way round to Guthega by end of the day and some final runs in Happy Valley, Copperhead Rd and home to front valley. The Superpipe is great when in along with each park area which has many features that work for all levels of skill. Perisher is a place where an advanced rider can find some decent challenging bespoke runs to some great beginner and progressive runs to help you transition into better on snow technique.

The beauty of Perisher is with many different facing aspects of ski areas you can normally find good snow somewhere on resort if you know where to look. Locals are friendly and happy to help in finding those areas of you are nice.

I've found Perisher to be one of the friendliest and good vibe snow fields anywhere I've been. Ski and board people get along mostly haha. It is what it is. But most people are nice and catch the vibe which can lead to great lift conversations and finding the good areas to hit first up.

The learner area is well setup with levels of progression even for learners. Only a good thing!

Mid Station is a great place as is blue cow for a beer and food. Normal resort prices like anywhere though. It costs money to get it all up there so cost is understandable I think.

Future wise what would I like to see?

Year pass separated into just Perisher and then the international one as another add on.

I'd like to see a cross country run like Copperhead Rd but from the top of mount P that runs around the back to Guthega. Used for Ski and board people of an advanced level.

On the transition trails between areas some off trail features would be cool too, like some small ramps etc as a pull over on the way trick for fun.

What would be the best addition? Joining forces with Charlotte's Pass and setting up a chair or gondola or extend the snow train out to Charlotte's so it opens even more up.

Facilities around Perisher, Blue Cow and Guthega are all dated but work well. 99% of the lift staff are great.

Getting to the snow from interstate is a challenge and it would be great to see Perisher advertise deals with Virgin or whoever for fly, drive, stay and ski packages through both Syd and Canberra. From the GC it would be great with a season pass to have a set rate to fly, drive or bus and accommodation at the snow. It would be a game changer.

Then I'd actually consider more weekend trips for a day of snow with travel either side.

I think all resorts, council and state gov need to extend the snow train to Jindy first and Cooma as a second option. It would bring more money and people into the region with them staying at Cooma and other towns on the way. Get Elon's Boring Company into it! A direct train connection out to Jindy from Canberra and Syd would also do nothing but bring more money into the region winter and summer.

My daughter, cousin and I spent the day at Perisher for some skiing. We had a great time overall, however some service areas could certainly do with some work. The hire centre at the bottom of the snow tube didn't have helpful staff at, compared with the staff at Thredbo who were very careful to properly fit skis and boots, and gave lots of tips for comfort. The runs at Perisher are lovely and far more expansive than Thredbo, but not always clearly marked which, particularly in heavy snow, can make navigation difficult. We frequently ended up around the backs of cabins and struggling to find the runs again. The lessons looked well run, and I like that the ski schools have a line for the lifts so xhildren can be added to lift groups, but unlike elsewhere the instructors didn't bother asking people if they minded helping the kids, and also didn't care that by forcibly pushing in they were separating my child from both of the adults she was with. Not acceptable. I will say though that the food court type area was great, with lots of options and friendly service. The runs were lovely and we will probably return, but hope to find better interpersonal skills from the staff next time.
Not easy for first timers. Make sure you hire equipment that you need beforehand as the queues can get really big.

Went there mid August, plenty of fresh snow. Rented some snow-shoes and poles in a little shop (35$/p for half day hire), lovely service, and for some good advice (start early, don't forget snacks and water). Did a 3h hike on the "porcupine track", very calm and relaxing walk.

They must have some portion where mothers can hang out special if there is a storm! Otherwise if I am single and ready to have some fun, I guess I would have given it 5 star. I hope my voice will be heard will be coming back next year

Perisher is old and tired. It poorly lacks modern amenities and decent spaces for people to hang out comfortably in between runs. Everyone handles the outdated and cramped conditions for the sake of the beautiful snow.

Resort coverage is large enough to get away from the crouds. Typically with a captive audience, prices are elevated but with a wide enough range of choices.
The resort itself combines four smaller resorts and features a large amount of lifts from the V8-Seater monster down to the carpark double, Tee bars (and Jay bars at Smiggins).
With the addition of snowguns and grooming the resort typically sees a good coverage, but when the wind comes in the outer limits of the resort (Perisher Mountain, Guthics and Blue Cow) shut down for safety.
Combine this with purpose built Jindabyne accomodation out at The Station and the SkiTube from Bullocks Flat, which is the best way to visit this resort daily.

Spent the last 6 days at Perisher on good snow under blue skies. I've never seen such good conditions for 6 consecutive days. The resort has plenty of ski runs for all levels from beginners up. There are several places to eat or grab a coffee all over the resort. They're all a bit pricey but I've come to expect that. For example, a large flat white coffee will set you back $6.90. All the staff on and off the snow that I have had anything to do with have been really nice. It's a great place to learn to ski for kids and adults alike. You can hire skis and boots etc there and there are plenty of shops at the main station to buy any ski apparel or accessories that you need. There is ski-in-ski-out accommodation available as well. I'll be going back in two weeks so if I think of anything else to add I will.

My friends and I snowboarded at Perisher for the last 7 days. We had 5 lessons with great, knowledgeable instructors who were really friendly. Office/sales staff have great customer service and are more than willing to help. On 3 occasions we were able to have our lessons changed from 9 to 11am due to arriving late from a dead car battery and stopping to put snow chains on. This was probably because it is not the peak season and there were still unbooked positions for the classes though. Lift operators were helpful with route recommendations and were friendly. I run blue trails and Perisher was more than fun and challenging enough for me. Outer Limits on Blue Cow had such good powder :O! Thredbo does seem to offer cheaper and more flexible lift and lesson packages, so I'll try it there next year and compare the routes.

Perisher has the best terrain parks in the Southern Hemisphere hands down. It makes the place a bit of a pro-shred gong show, and the local scene can be a bit too-cool-for-school, but the staff is kind, the snow isn't half bad and the parks are creative. So that's that!

In my opinion Perisher is the best ski resort in Australia. It has a large quantity of good runs for all abilities and it's staff are component and friendly. That said I urge people to consider the true cost of sking at Perisher. For example the cost of buying a lift pass is extremely high. For my wife and I to ski for three days it cost us $780 just for lift passes. Couple that with the cost of buying a three day pass just to get your car into the park costing nearly $90. The food on site will also cost you a arm and a leg, a hot chocolate will be nearly $10, a bottle of water $6 and the food is of mediocre taste and quality. To add insult to injury they have no facilities to enable you to be self contained so you have to rely on there on site catering facilities. Then you have the cost of hiring your gear and paying for accommodation on top of all that. I assure you that by the time you ad all of this up you may wonder why on earth it cost so much. Consider your options, it may be almost cheaper to go over seas to do the same thing in Japan where the powder can be sensational. In summary Perisher is a great ski resort but it comes at a rich mans price I'm not sure the value for money is really there.

I had this terrible experience with serge's cafe Smiggin today. After ordering $50 worth of food I went back to the counter wanting to find out where I can find tomato sauce for hot chips I ordered for my kids. While I was quietly waiting the guy at the counter suddenly screamed out rudely to me" go away, we don't have hot water!!!!" I was totally in shock then realised as I was holding a coffee in my hand, the guy assumed I was asking for hot water like lots of Asian tourists would ask?I don't think there is anything wrong with asking for hot water even I do ask for it?! But in this situation I was extremely upset to be screamed at without even saying anything?!So I explained to the guy that I only tried to ask where to find tomato sauce. The guy then answered rudly "well I made a judgement call then!!". There was no intention of any apology I was really upset therefore I raised my voice asking him to apologise! The guy looked angry and impatient but what's worse was that as the same time he handed me the tomato sauce he threw my $4 change ( 2 coins)on the ground!!! On purpose!! In front of hundred people!!'
I picked up my money and walked away. Feeling humiliated and angry!
I am still in total shock as our tourists guide says we Chinese bring so many tourists each year to Smiggin and this is how we get treated?!? Most of Chinese of my parents generation can't speak English they would have just walked away in this situation  .I wonder if that's the reason they think they can be rude to us however they like but if we do complain they would just throw the money on the ground and ask us to go away?!!!

Unbelievable!!'!
Shame on you bullies!!!

If you come on a good season, you're going to have a blast. Lots of runs ranging from the smooth and wind to the long and windy. On a sunny day you'd almost consider going down in a shirt, it's so pleasant. Just bring money and lots of it. If you're planning in advance, do yourself a favor and book early to save some cash.
Good open terrain. Great for exploring off piste.

Great resort area with lots of lifts and nice groomed runs catering for all abilities. Be sure to visit Guthega when you go there.

1. Purchased private lesson with instructor at 11am for 1pm.
The weather was absolutely bad, raining (not snowing! ), strong wind, etc.
I came back 5 mins later and said that kids are already wet through,  they don't want to do anything outside and till 1pm they will be sick, angry and cold! So i asked for refund. No refund was given. I asked to change the dates, they wanted to charge me more.
No customer service,  all about getting more money!

2. I came with 2 kids: 1 - 4years old; 2 - 8years old. They had never done skiing  before. So obviously they were not going to ski on ALL 47 LIFTS!!! And obviously i had to stay with them teaching the moves.  It's absolutely ridiculous to make kids and parents pay for the whole resort lifts and especially knowing that a parent is stuck with them (no, i did not want to pay ~150$ per kid per day and leave them in the school, because i came to perisher to spend time with my children while school holidays are on! So we enjoy being together!)
I had to spend ~130$ just to be able to go on kid's "magic carpet" with my little ones to be able to hold them while they are sliding  (falling) down. Is that fair??? Did I get to enjoy the whole perisher lifts?? NO!!!
It's all about making as much money as you can!!! Monopoly!

Here is the great suggestion! Why don't you make 1 main 8 seats lift and magic carpet for newbies/kids/parents (guardian ) so we can pay acceptable fee so we don't regret coming here spending all this money for what? For service i did not get?? Would we want now to come back to perisher and recommend you! ? ....

Just make separate coded pass card that works only on 1-2 lifts so people feel that you are not trying to rip them off!!!
